,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Following the album release, French announced signing [[Chicago]]-based rapper [[Lil Durk]] to his Coke Boys. French, who is close to producer [[Young Chop]], had previously collaborated with Durk on his recent mixtape and with Chief Keef on his debut album the year before. Durk, Chinx and Young Chop appeared in the music video to \"Paranoid\", featuring Chop's brother Johnny May Cash. The song is inspired by French's brushes with death, including the late-2003 incident where he survived a gunshot to the head. Durk collaborated on several records with French in the coming years, starting with the remix to Durk's breakout single \"[[Dis Ain't What U Want]]\" featuring French, Ross and Meek Mill, released on November 27, 2013.
French appeared as a featured artist on several singles in 2013, most notably [[Joe Budden]]'s \"[[NBA (song)
thumb: NBA]]\" with Wiz Khalifa released on March 26; [[ASAP Ferg]]'s \"[[Trap Lord
250px]]: Work (Remix)]]\" – alongside [[Schoolboy Q]], [[ASAP Rocky]] and [[Trinidad James]] – on May 14; Canadian singer [[Massari]]'s \"[[Shisha (song)
column4: Shisha]]\" on May 21; and [[Will.i.am]]'s \"[[Feelin' Myself (will.i.am song)
column5: Feelin Myself]]\" with Miley Cyrus and Wiz Khalifa on November 26, among others.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Despite several pushbacks, French released his seventeenth mixtape ''Coke Boys 4'' on January 2, 2014,<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana Sticks To His Comfort Zone On 'Coke Boys 4' Mixtape
column6: accessdate=January 9, 2014}}</ref> which included collaborations with [[Snoop Dogg]], [[Wiz Khalifa]], [[MGK]], Mally Mall, [[Lil Durk]] and MeetSims, among others. The music video for the \"Paranoid (Remix)\" – featuring Diddy, Ross, Meek, Durk, Chinx and Jadakiss – was released on April 13. Subsequent music videos included, \"88 Coupes\" featuring Jadakiss released on May 15, \"God Body\" featuring Chinx on May 28, and \"Money Bag\" with Durk and Chinx on June 23. In a January 2014 ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' interview, French revealed that his next ''Mac & Cheese'' would be a studio album instead of a mixtape.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=French Montana Working With Kanye, Macklemore and Rick Ross

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 2014, French collaborated with Diddy on Ross' track \"[[Nobody (Rick Ross song)
thumb: Nobody]]\" released on February 19. Rick Ross' remake of the late Notorious B.I.G.'s 1997 song \"[[Life After Death
250px]]: You're Nobody (Til Somebody Kills You)]]\", featured an eerie chorus by French and interludes of Diddy in a live motivational rant. The song was inspired by Ross' brush against death the year before, when his [[Rolls-Royce Motors
column4: Rolls-Royce]] came under repeated gunshot fire while driving through [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida
column7: title=Rick Ross Masterminds Death-Defying Return: Video Q&A + Photo Shoot Behind-The-Scenes
column11: accessdate=March 23, 2014}}</ref> In a bizarre series of events, French Montana would experience a similar but unrelated event months later when his convoy came under fire on March 1 in [[Philadelphia]] during his \"Excuse My French\" tour after French had finished performing a show hours earlier.<ref name=\"MTVphilly2\">{{cite web
column13: title= French Montana Says He ‘Was Not Involved’ In Philadelphia Shooting
column18: title=Shooting Outside Rapper’s Tour Bus Leaves 1 Dead, 1 Wounded
column21: accessdate=July 21, 2015}}</ref> The music video premiered on February 27, 2014. Albeit met with mixed to positive reviews, the song would be a hit and was re-released as a single on March 3, 2014. French joined Ross for a live performance on the television program ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]'' on March 5, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Rick Ross Performs \"Nobody\" with French Montana on the \"Late Night with Seth Meyers\"

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French Montana would collaborate with fellow-Bronx native [[Jennifer Lopez]] on her comeback single \"[[I Luh Ya Papi]]\". The song premiered on LA's [[Power 106]] in March 5, and was released as a single on March 11, with the music video coming out two days later. The single was an international hit, and among the most added/played tracks on [[rhythmic contemporary]] radio in Canada. French also appeared in the music video to Fat Joe's single \"Stressin\", featuring Jennifer Lopez, which premiered in October later that year. French joined Rick Ross on [[Puff Daddy]]'s comeback single \"Big Homie\" from his upcoming album ''MMM''. With a guest verse by Ross and ad-libs by French, the single was released on March 24, with the music video premiering on March 31. French Montana joined Ross, Meek and veteran [[Jay-Z]] on [[DJ Khaled]]'s summer hit \"[[They Don't Love You No More]]\". The single was released on March 29, with the music video coming out on June 22 that year.
On July 17, teasers to the movie ''[[The Purge: Anarchy]]'' were released featuring music from French's upcoming single \"[[Don't Panic (French Montana song)
thumb: Don't Panic]]\". A month earlier, Instagram photos of the two showed French with then-girlfriend [[Khloé Kardashian]] on set with matching masks on, prompting speculation whether she was in the coming video. Following weeks of promotion, the single was released on August 12. The music video, which retained the dark themes of the movie while maintaining its catchy [[DJ Mustard]] character, became a viral hit. The couple had created bit of a stir two months earlier, on June 2, when Khloé posted an IG photo of the two on set of \"They Don't Love You No More\", depicting French holding a rifle in his arms with Khloé seated next to him with a bottle of liquor to her mouth. The remix to \"Don't Panic\", featuring Jeremih and Chris Brown, was released on October 14.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French Montana would join [[Remy Ma]] on DJ Khaled's \"They Don't Love You No More (Remix)\" released on August 2. Khaled's former [[Terror Squad (group)
thumb: Terror Squad]] affiliate and Bronx-native Remy Ma had just been released from prison the day prior. The three appeared together in the music video which premiered on August 23.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title= DJ Khaled Feat. Remy Ma & French Montana – They Don't Love You No More Remix
column6: accessdate=August 31, 2015}}</ref> This was her first musical comeback since her incarceration six years earlier. French collaborated with [[Ashanti (singer)
column7: Ashanti]] on her second single \"[[Braveheart (Ashanti album)
column8: Early In The Morning]]\" released on October 14 off of her comeback album, ''Braveheart''. This would be Ashanti's first album in six years.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French released his second single \"[[Bad Bitch]]\", featuring Jeremih, in December 2014, with the music video premiering on February 23, 2015. In late-October, French had announced his \"Set It Off\" tour with Jeremih, running up to his expected ''Mac & Cheese: The Album'' release in December. With the album eventually pushed back to next year; in its place, French released his collaborative [[extended play
thumb: EP]] with Harry Fraud, ''Mac & Cheese: The Appetizer'' on December 12, 2014.<ref name=\"FM18\">{{cite web
column4: title= French Montana – Mac & Cheese: The Appetizer
column6: date=December 12, 2014}}</ref> His eighteenth mixtape, ''The Appetizer'' marked a shift away from French's usual feature-heavy records. With Fraud's signature sample-heavy production, French blurred the lines between rap and R&B in a manner not unlike that of Max B, and with subject matter ranging from difficult life-decisions, women, addiction and memories of his bygone friendship with his now-incarcerated rap soulmate. In August 2015, French paired with pop-opera artist [[Charisse Mills]] for the single \"Champagne.\"<ref name = allhiphop>{{cite web
column8: title = Charisse Mills Ft. French Montana – \"Champagne\"

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On February 14, 2016, [[DJ Khaled]] announced that he would debut French's new mixtape on [[We The Best
thumb: We The Best Radio]].<ref name=\"DJ Khaled to premiere French Montana's mixtape\">{{cite web
column4: title=DJ Khaled to premiere French Montana's mixtape
column8: accessdate=February 14, 2016}}</ref> The mixtape, hosted by Max B, debuted on February 19, 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column14: accessdate=February 20, 2016}}</ref> On May 5, 2016, French's contract with Interscope and MMG ended, and he later signed a joint venture record deal with Bad Boy and [[Epic Records]].<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=French Montana Signs With Epic Records
column21: accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> Later, French was going to release his second studio album ''[[MC4 (mixtape)
column22: MC4]]'' in October 2016, however, the album's release was canceled after [[Target Corporation
column23: Target]] unofficially released the album on [[Compact disc
column24: CD]] on its original release date (August 19, 2016), two months before the album was set to release, which also managed to leak its entirety on internet as a [[internet leak
column25: leak]], plus some \"sample clearance issues\" on tracks like \"I'm Heated\" and 2 Times\".<ref name=\"Scrapped\">{{cite web
column28: title=French Montana Ain't Worried about Scrapping 'MC4' (Exclusive)
column31: accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> It was originally supposed to be the fourth installment in the \"Mac & Cheese\" series, and the first to be originally released as an album. French later stated that he's planning to start a new record label with Max B when he is released. On November 5, 2016, Montana unexpectedly released the album as a [[mixtape]] instead and premiered it on [[Drake (musician)
column32: Drake]]'s [[Beats 1]] radio show, [[OVO Sound]] radio later that night. Montana revealed in an interview with [[Zane Lowe]] on his [[Beats 1]] radio show that the first and second single from his upcoming project is ready to be released. He also announced a collaborative track with [[Chance the Rapper]] and [[Quavo]], produced by Ben Billions, a collaboration with [[Swae Lee]] that is \"just like 'Unforgettable'\", as well as a song called \"No Stylist\".<ref>{{cite news
column35: title=French Montana & Swae Lee Are Sitting On The Next \"Unforgettable\"
column40: title=New Music: Diplo, French Montana, & Lil Pump feat. Zhavia – 'Welcome to the Party'

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On July 14, 2017 Montana released ''[[Jungle Rules]]'' as his second album.
On December 6, 2019, French Montana released his third studio album ''[[Montana (album)
thumb: Montana]]'', which includes the song \"[[Writing on the Wall (French Montana song)
250px]]: Writing on the Wall]]\", a collaboration with [[Cardi B]], [[Post Malone]] and [[Rvssian]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Montana's charitable work started after he visited Uganda to film his \"[[Unforgettable (French Montana song)
thumb: Unforgettable]]\" video in 2017, a song that gained over a billion streams and held strong on the top 10 in the U.S. [[Billboard Hot 100]]. His efforts in Uganda raised half a million dollars to build the Suubi hospital which serves over 300,000 citizens of Uganda. <ref> {{cite news
column5: title= French Montana Launches Global Healthcare Initiative, Donates $100K to Mama Hope Organization in Uganda: Exclusive}}</ref>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 2018, French was given the honor of Global Citizen Ambassador for his charity work in the East African country, Uganda. This was the first time the honor has been bestowed upon a rapper.<ref> {{cite news
250px]]: title=French Montana Donated $100K to Uganda and Became Rap's First-Ever Global Citizen Ambassador

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Montana is fluent in his [[Languages of Morocco
thumb: native]] Arabic and French as well as in English.<ref name=\"fader\"/><ref name=\"StatusMag\"/> He cites being a father as one of his driving inspirations.<ref name=\"StatusMag\">{{cite news

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Montana has been a resident of the [[Pompton Plains, New Jersey
thumb: Pompton Plains]] section of [[Pequannock Township, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite news
column6: title= French Montana Talks New Album, Kanye and Media Attention on His Relationship With Khloe Kardashian
column11: quote= On a sweltering afternoon, a camera flashes on French Montana at his new house in suburban Pompton Plains, N.J.}}</ref> In 2016, he bought [[Selena Gomez]]'s [[Calabasas, California
column14: title= French Montana buys old crib

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Montana married Deen Kharbouch in 2007. The couple had separated by 2012, and their divorce was finalized in 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=French Montana: Rapper Officially Divorces Wife Dean Kharbouch
column9: title= French Montana – Ain't Worried 'Bout Nothin ... Finally Divorced
column13: date=October 3, 2014}}</ref> They have a son who was born in 2010.<ref name= worried />

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In June 2018, Montana became a [[citizen of the United States of America
thumb: U.S. citizen]].<ref>[http://www.tmz.com/2018/06/14/french-montana-becomes-u-s-citizen/ French Montana becomes US citizen] [[TMZ.com]] 2018/06/14</ref><ref>[http://www.thefader.com/2018/06/14/french-montana-united-states-citizen French Montana becomes United States citizen] ''The Fader'',  2018/06/14</ref>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 2003, two gunmen shot at Montana as he left a recording studio in New York, striking him in the head.<ref name=\"Life+Times\"/><ref name=\"CombatJack3\">{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana Casually Discusses Taking A Bullet To The Brain – The Combat Jack Show Episode 3
column6: accessdate=August 15, 2015}}</ref> He survived and was hospitalized for several weeks.<ref name=\"USmag\">{{cite web
column8: title=French Montana Says He's Not Dating Khloé Kardashian For Fame, Recalls Getting Shot In Head
column13: title=French Montana Talks Record Deal, Ross & Akon
column16: accessdate=September 2, 2013}}</ref> One of the gunmen died during the incident, in what is believed to be a case of \"[[friendly fire]]\" by one assailant against the other. Montana was investigated for the incident, but the case was eventually dismissed.<ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/><ref name=\"CombatJack3\"/><ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Shot In The Head & Beat Murder Case
column21: accessdate=August 9, 2015}}</ref> In early 2013, Montana visited the site of the shooting with a camera crew from Life+Times as he recalled the near-death experience and his life growing up in the Bronx. This was the first time he had visited the location since the attempted murder ten years earlier.<ref name=\"Life+Times\">{{cite web
column23: title=French Montana Tells His Story – The Genesis
column26: accessdate=July 21, 2015}}</ref> According to French, he was set up by someone close to him and his circle.<ref name= \"Life+Times\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French has been the owner of a number of pets, ranging from dogs to exotic animals such as [[tigers]] and a [[monkey]]. On April 22, 2013, French Montana posted an Instagram picture with the caption \"Got so high last night bought 2 baby tigers\". The picture was of French outdoors holding two tiger cubs, one on each arm.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana Gets High, Purchases Baby Tigers
column6: accessdate=July 22, 2015}}</ref> The tigers, named Ike and Tina, were prominently featured in French's music video for \"[[Excuse My French (album)
column7: The Gifted]]\" featuring friend and singer [[The Weeknd]], released later that year.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=BTS of French Montana and The Weekend's Music Video \"The Gifted\"
column14: title=French Montana and The Weekend Play With Tigers In \"The Gifted\" Video
column17: accessdate=July 22, 2015}}</ref>  In 2014, the rapper noted he had given up the two tigers shortly after getting them, citing the difficulty in feeding and caring for the animals.<ref name= \"Ridiculousness\">{{cite web

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Since late-2014, French Montana became the owner of a pet monkey named Julius Ceasor. A video of the animal was uploaded on December 18, showing French and record producer Mally Mall entering a private-jet with French then cradling the infant monkey in his arms.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana Introduces His Pet Monkey Julius Ceasor
column8: title=Exclusive: Mally Mall Gifts French Montana With a Monkey!

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French Montana describes [[Tupac Shakur]], [[The Notorious B.I.G.]], [[Nas]], [[Snoop Dogg]], and [[Wu-Tang Clan]] among the hip hop artists he listened to growing up.<ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/><ref name=\"StatusMag\"/><ref name=\"BallerStatus2012\">{{cite web
column5: title=French Montana: Talks Indie Grind, Diddy's Business Sense & Max B
column8: accessdate=January 7, 2013}}</ref> He considers himself a music lover in general, and admires the work of [[England
column9: English]] soul/R&B singers [[Adele]] and [[Amy Winehouse]],<ref name=\"StatusMag\"/> the English rock band [[Florence + the Machine]],<ref name=\"Hot97single2\">{{cite web
column11: title=French Montana Speaks On Overseas Groupies, Working With Max B & Going On Tour With Chris Brown?
column15: accessdate=July 22, 2015}}</ref> and American singer [[Lana Del Rey]], several of whom he has sampled in his music.

column4: title=French Montana & Lil Boosie Announce New Movies

250px]]: title=See Nominees for the African Muzik Magazine Awards (AFRIMMA) 2014

column4: title=2013 BET Hip Hop Awards: The Complete Winners List

thumb: Reese's Perfect Combo Award (Best Collabo, Duo or Group)<ref name=\"mtv.com\"/>

250px]]: \"[[All the Way Up (Fat Joe and Remy Ma song)
column4: All the Way Up]]\" <small>(with [[Fat Joe]] & [[Remy Ma]], and Infared)</small>
title=Billboard Music Awards 2015: See the Full List of Finalists

column6: title=Grammy Nominations 2016: See the Full List of Nominees

250px]]: \"[[All the Way Up (Fat Joe and Remy Ma song)
column4: All the Way Up]]\" <small>(with [[Fat Joe]] & [[Remy Ma]] and Infared)</small>

}}; born November 9, 1984), better known by his [[stage name]] '''French Montana''', is a Moroccan-American rapper. Born and raised in [[Morocco]], he immigrated to the United States with his family when he was 13.<ref name=\"fader\"/><ref name=\"SDinterview\"/> He is the founder of Coke Boys Records, and its predecessor Cocaine City Records. After years of independent material, he was signed as joint-venture record deal with [[Sean Combs
column5: Puff Daddy]]'s [[Bad Boy Records]] and [[Rick Ross]]'s [[Maybach Music Group]] in 2012.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Kharbouch released his mixtape debut in 2007, and had his first breakthrough with the single \"Choppa Choppa Down\" in 2010. He released his debut studio album ''[[Excuse My French (album)
thumb: Excuse My French]]'' on May 21, 2013.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=French Montana's \"Excuse My French\" Pushed Back Again
column6: accessdate=March 8, 2013}}</ref> In July 2017, Montana released his second studio album, ''[[Jungle Rules]]'', which peaked at number three on the [[Billboard 200
column7: ''Billboard'' 200]]. The album was supported by the single \"[[Unforgettable (French Montana song)
column8: Unforgettable]]\", featuring [[Swae Lee]], which became Montana's first song as lead artist to reach the top 10 on the [[Billboard Hot 100

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Karim Kharbouch was born on November 9, 1984, in [[Casablanca]], Morocco.<ref name=\"fader\"/> He grew up at the family estate outside [[Casablanca]] where he lived for the first 13 years of his life.<ref name=\"fader\">{{cite web
column6: accessdate=January 9, 2014}}</ref> Growing up, he was consumed with [[association football
column7: soccer]] and rap, describing them as his two favorite childhood hobbies,<ref name=\"SDinterview\">{{cite web
column9: title=Stupid Dope interview with French Montana
column15: url-status=dead }}</ref> before getting into basketball in his later teens.<ref name=\"CombatJack1\">{{cite web
column17: title=French Montana Talks About Max B & The Street DVD Hustle – The Combat Jack Show Episode 1

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In the mid-1990s, Kharbouch left Morocco with his parents and younger brother for [[New York City]], where they settled in the [[South Bronx]].<ref name=fader/> Kharbouch spoke only his [[Languages of Morocco
thumb: native languages]] of [[Moroccan Darija]] and French when he first arrived, and learned English in the streets and in the Bronx high schools of Lehman and Roosevelt.<ref name=fader/> After struggling for two years, his father decided they would move back to Casablanca, but his mother opted to stay back with their children citing lack of opportunities back home.<ref name=fader/> His mother was pregnant with his youngest brother at the time, who was born in the United States shortly after his father departed for Morocco. With three children, his mother was dependent on welfare for financial support. Kharbouch eventually found himself the primary breadwinner for the family.<ref name=fader/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French Montana began his career as a [[battle rap]]per in his teens under the name Young French. In 2002, French and close friend Cams created a series of street DVDs called ''Cocaine City'', drawing inspiration from the ''Smack'' DVD series popular at the time.<ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\">{{cite web
column9: title=How They Came Up: The French Montana Story
column11: accessdate=August 8, 2015}}</ref> The series featured interviews with major and upcoming rappers, personalities, and a focus on street music and hip hop beefs.<ref name=fader/><ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/><ref name=\"RapFixLive\"/> Initially as Young French, he used the DVDs as a means of showcasing his talent as an underground artist, including in it his own original music, freestyles, and collaborations with other artists. The first volume in the series featured [[Pee Wee Kirkland]] and [[Remy Ma]] among others.<ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/><ref name=\"CombatJack1\"/> What started out as a medium for developing an audience, quickly grew into one of the top-selling street DVDs.<ref name=\"IndieHipHop\"/> The series ran for eight years between 2002–2010, totaling 14 volumes, and multiple spinoff films. Based out of the Bronx, French ran the series with the help of childhood friends including Brock, Droop Pop and Cheeze, who went on to become the first rappers that formed the Coke Boys.<ref name=\"HHVibeBrock\">{{cite web
column13: title=Coke Boy Brock talks \"The Blackout 2\" and history with the Coke Boys
column17: title=The Hype Magazine Interviews Cokeboy Brock

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 2003, French suffered a gunshot to the head when he was confronted by two armed gunmen as he was leaving a recording studio in the Bronx.<ref name=\"Life+Times\"/><ref name=\"USmag\"/><ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/> The incident resulted in one of the gunmen dead, in what is believed to be a case of \"[[friendly fire]]\" by one assailant against the other.<ref name=\"Life+Times\"/><ref name=\"CombatJack3\"/> French was then hospitalized for several weeks.<ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/><ref name=\"CombatJack3\"/> Upon discharge, he discovered that he was set up by someone close to him and his circle.<ref name=\"Life+Times\"/>

In 2007, French Montana released his debut mixtape ''French Revolution Vol. 1'', which included collaborations with [[Uncle Murda]], [[Jae Millz]], [[Mazaradi Fox]] and [[Tony Yayo]]. The track \"Quarter to Eight\" was the first of many collaborations with [[Rick Ross]]. The [[J.Cardim]]-produced \"Straight Cash\" was French's first underground hit. In 2008, he released his second mixtape, ''Live From Africa''.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=February 22, 2016}}</ref> The song \"Waavvy\" was the first collaboration with rapper [[Max B]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French Montana and Max B released their debut collaborative mixtape ''[[Coke Wave]]'' on February 6, 2009. A few weeks later, on February 23, Max B's mixtape ''Quarantine'' was released, while French released his ''The Laundry Man'' on February 24, 2009.<ref>{{cite web
column5: date=February 24, 2009}}</ref> The two artists resumed concentrating on their solo records, until the release of their second collaborative mixtape ''Coke Wave 2'' in November that year.

thumb: XXL]]'s Freshman Class of 2012. At that time he had already been signed to [[Bad Boy Records]] following the success of his single \"Shot Caller\", and had just signed a joint-venture between Bad Boy and [[Maybach Music Group]].<ref name=\"RapFixLive\">{{cite web
column4: title=French Montana Wasn't Gonna Do XXL Freshman Cover

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In an interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine, close friend and producer [[Harry Fraud]] revealed first meeting French Montana during a recording session at a studio in [[Chinatown, Manhattan
column4: title=The Old-Fashioned Values of Producer Harry Fraud
column7: accessdate=August 12, 2015}}</ref> Fraud recalls recording a song for someone which French happened to have a guest feature on. In an unusual turn of events, the building was [[police raid
column8: raided]] by police after a tip-off that there were counterfeit Gucci and Louis Vuitton purses being manufactured at the same building.<ref name=\"HarryFraudRS\"/> Having lost his studio spot, Fraud went on to form his own studio in Brooklyn, where the two \"met and formed a bond\".<ref name=\"HarryFraudRS\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Harry Fraud, who hails from a musical family background and had interned at a [[recording studio]],<ref name=\"HarryFraudL+T\">{{cite web
250px]]: title=Harry Fraud Speaks On His Sound, Producing For French Montana & New Label
column6: accessdate=August 12, 2015}}</ref> was still unknown professionally at the time. The two released their first collaboration \"New York Minute\", featuring [[Jadakiss]], off of French's fifth mixtape ''Mac Wit Da Cheese'' released on April 19, 2009.<ref name=\"FM5\">{{cite web
column8: title= ''French Montana – Mac Wit Da Cheese''
column10: date= April 19, 2009}}</ref> Following its success, the two artists recorded \"We Playin In The Wind\" off of French's sixth mixtape ''The Laundry Man 2'' released on June 29.<ref>{{cite web
column14: date=June 29, 2009}}</ref> With \"New York Minute\" still buzzing in the city, rapper [[Ma$e]] would approach French Montana to hop on the remix,<ref name=\"ChoppaRoss\"/> included in French's eighth mixtape ''Coke Wave 2'' released in November. Since then, Harry Fraud's production has been a staple among French's music, and Fraud has since ventured out into working with various other artists. Fraud gained mainstream attention when his track with French Montana \"[[Shot Caller (French Montana song)
column15: Shot Caller]]\" became one of the most added tracks on [[urban contemporary]] radio in 2011–2012.<ref name=\"SDinterview\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Starting in 2009, French Montana had signed a deal with [[Akon]] and his [[Konvict Music]] label.<ref name=\"AkonAcevedo\"/> The two previously met in Miami in 2008,<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=February 23, 2016}}</ref> and later appeared on [[DJ Green Lantern]]'s \"Invasion Radio\" on [[SiriusXM]]'s [[Hip-Hop Nation]].<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=DJ Green Lantern & French Montana Freestyle w/ Akon
column12: accessdate=September 6, 2015}}</ref> The pair collaborated on a series of tracks including their first single \"Married to the Streets\" on French's seventh mixtape ''Cocaine Konvicts'' released on September 25.<ref>{{cite web
column16: date=September 25, 2009}}</ref><ref name=\"GabyAcevedo\"/> In later interviews, French revealed that he had a \"shopping deal\" with Akon for a six months to a year period.<ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/><ref name=\"ParleMag\"/> \"A shopping deal is when an artist takes a liking in you, and they try to take you to a label to get you signed. I was gonna go get signed to his label, but they were going through problems with [[Interscope Records
column17: Interscope]]. [As a result] my deal was over with him, so I went and did my own thing\", claimed French in his 2012 interview with Complex.<ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/> Akon, whom French refers to as \"big brother\",<ref name=\"BadBoyKonvict\"/> would continue to maintain a relationship with French, collaborating on songs together despite the unsuccessful deal between the two.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French had met Akon through their mutual friend Gaby Acevedo.<ref name=\"AkonAcevedo\"/><ref name=\"GabyAcevedo\">{{cite web
250px]]: title= How to Make It in America: French Montana's Manager Gaby Acevedo on How to Manage a Musician
column7: accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> Acevedo was then-president of [[SRC Records]] – under founder and chairman [[Steve Rifkind]] — the label first responsible for breaking out artists such as Akon, [[David Banner]], and [[Remy Ma]], then a member of Fat Joe's [[Terror Squad (group)
column8: Terror Squad]].<ref name=\"GabyAcevedo\"/> Acevedo, whom French had befriended during his time working on the ''Cocaine City'' DVDs, had put his music on to Akon who then approached French inviting him to meet him in [[Florida]].<ref name=\"AkonAcevedo\">{{cite web
column10: title= French Montana Wants A Piece Of Akon’s Success
column13: accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"GabyAcevedo\"/> Although the Akon deal was short-lived, Acevedo would eventually go on to become French's manager following his mainstream breakout. In 2012, with Rifkind leaving SRC's parent company [[Universal Music Group]] in September, the SRC imprint would close shop as well. With French's management deal with Mizay Entertainment having recently ended, Gaby Acevedo would postpone retirement to become his new manager, where he now spends his time on the road touring with French.<ref name=\"GabyAcevedo\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: ===2010–11: Choppa Choppa Down and southern breakout===

French released his tenth mixtape ''Coke Boys'' on September 15, 2010, which included collaborations with [[Three 6 Mafia]], [[Gucci Mane]], Akon, [[Fat Joe]], fellow Coke Boys, among others.<ref name=\"FM10\">{{cite web
column5: date=September 15, 2009}}</ref> The record which included the track \"Choppa Choppa Down\", featuring [[Waka Flocka Flame]], became a hit among clubs and radio throughout the [[Southern United States
column8: title=A Guide to French Montana's Mixtapes
column14: title=French Montana: \"Teachers Call Me\", Drake’s Beef \"Happens\"
column17: accessdate=August 27, 2015}}</ref> Waka Flocka, who recently broken into the mainstream with his single \"[[Hard In Da Paint]]\" released on May 13, had recorded the song earlier that year while Gucci Mane was still in prison. An early remix to the song, featuring French Montana, was included in French's ninth mixtape ''Mac & Cheese 2'' released earlier that year on May 6 and which also included collaborations with rising stars [[Wiz Khalifa]], Nicki Minaj, [[Big Sean]], [[Curren$y]] and [[Nipsey Hussle]] among others.<ref name=\"FM9\">{{cite web
column21: date=May 6, 2010}}</ref> The two respective breakout tracks would kick off the start of a close relationship between French and Waka Flocka, where the two describe themselves as being \"brothers\".<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Waka Flocka Says French Montana Deal Is ‘Amazing’

thumb: XXL]] magazine reported on French Montana having signed with [[Atlanta]]-based management firm Mizay Entertainment, headed by Debra Antney.<ref name=\"XXLmizay\">{{cite web
column4: title=French Montana Signs With Debra Antney’s Mizay Entertainment
column8: accessdate=August 20, 2015}}</ref> Debra, who is Waka Flocka's mother, was also manager to Gucci Mane, [[OJ Da Juiceman]], rising star [[Lex Luger]] and the [[808 Mafia]] production team, and formerly [[Nicki Minaj]] prior to her mainstream breakout.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Mizay Entertainment's Deb Antney Calls Nicki Minaj Her \"First Born Child\" Of Being Successful
column15: title=Debra Antney Talks Discovering Gucci Mane, French Montana, & Nicki Minaj, \"LHHATL\" & More
column18: accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> The music video for \"Choppa Choppa Down\",<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=French Montana – Choppa Choppa Down ft. Waka Flocka Flame
column24: accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> which featured a [[Black Hawk Down (film)
column25: Black Hawk Down]] theme, was released in late-January and included cameos from Gucci, [[Shawty Lo]], DJ Holiday and members of [[Brick Squad Monopoly]].<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=French Montana Drops Video, Looks To Record With Lady Gaga
column32: title=Behind The Scenes: French Montana (Feat. Waka Flocka) – Choppa Down (Starring Gucci Mane, Shawty Lo, Brick Squad & More!)
column36: accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> With the success of the ''Coke Boys'' mixtape and his recent management deal with Debra, French adopted a recurring [[Trap music (hip hop)
column37: trap]] influence among his music. in 2013, Debra Antney sued French Montana for dealing behind her back for commission. In 2017, Debra won the [[lawsuit]] against him for which he was obliged to pay $2 million to Debra.<ref>{{Cite web
column39: title=French Montana Reportedly Ordered to Pay Waka Flocka’s Mother $2 Million

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On February 15, French released his eleventh mixtape ''[[Mister 16: Casino Life]]'', which featured productions from Fraud and [[Lex Luger]] among others, including his soon-to-be next hit \"Shot Caller\".<ref name=\"FM11\">{{cite web
column5: date=February 15, 2011}}</ref> The tape's combination of hard trap beats alongside the more soulful beats – such as those of his New York producer Harry Fraud – would become a fixture among French's music. The latter sound being further explored in his twelfth mixtape ''Coke Boys 2'' released on August 19,<ref name=\"FM12\">{{cite web
column9: date=August 19, 2011}}</ref> providing a softer break from his more robust tapes that year. Both records have been acclaimed for their production and hooks. French would continue on his increasing presence in the South, releasing his collaborative mixtape with Waka Flocka called ''Lock Out'' on December 14. That same month, he would release his long-awaited collaborative mixtape ''[[Cocaine Mafia]]'' with [[Memphis, Tennessee
column10: Memphis]]-based rappers [[Juicy J]] and [[Project Pat]], released on December 19.<ref name=\"FM14\">{{cite web
column12: title=''French Montana, Juicy J & Project Pat – Cocaine Mafia''
column14: date=December 19, 2011}}</ref> This would be French's thirteenth and fourteenth mixtapes, respectively. With four records out in 2011, it would be his busiest year of releases since 2009. In a 2012 interview with Parlé magazine, French revealed his deal with Mizay Entertainment as having been for a year and a half.<ref name=\"ParleMag\">{{cite web
column16: title= French Montana Interview: Rise From Cocaine City

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: With French's growing buzz in the South, he was approached by [[Florida]]-based rapper [[Rick Ross]] who invited him to his studio.<ref name=\"ChoppaRoss\">{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana Talks Rick Ross and Possibly Signing to MMG
column7: accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> French, who admits having been a fan of Ross' music, was invited to come \"at like three in the morning\" where he listened to his upcoming [[Maybach Music Group
column8: MMG]] collaborative album ''[[Self Made Vol. 1]]''.<ref name=\"ChoppaRoss\"/> The two recorded a track for the album, while Ross hopped on the remix to \"Choppa Choppa Down\".<ref name=\"ChoppaRoss\"/> The new single, which also featured Wiz Khalifa, was released on April 28, 2011, with the music video coming out in June.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=French Montana Ft. Rick Ross & Wiz Khalifa – Choppa Choppa Down (Remix)
column14: accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> An earlier remix featuring Gucci Mane and Wiz Khalifa had been released on March 25. The collaboration would mark the start of French's relationship with Rick Ross and his [[Maybach Music Group]], prompting speculation whether French would be signing to the label.<ref name=\"ChoppaRoss\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: ===2011–12: Shot Caller and New York takeover===
With French juggling between Atlanta and New York, his song \"[[Shot Caller (French Montana song)
thumb: Shot Caller]]\" off of the ''Casino Life'' record would gain traction on New York radio beginning mid-2011. During an on-air interview with [[Fat Joe]] on [[DJ Green Lantern]]'s \"Invasion Radio\" in October 2011, French would call in to praise close friend and fellow-[[Bronx]] rapper Fat Joe, revealing his role in helping to get \"Shot Caller\" on the airwaves.<ref name=\"FatJoeSiriusXM\">{{cite web
column4: title= French Montana Calls His \"Big Brother\" Fat Joe On Invasion Radio
column7: accessdate=August 20, 2015}}</ref> Fat Joe, whom he refers to as \"big brother\", praised French's work ethic and revealed that French had been receiving offers from several major labels.<ref name=\"FatJoeSiriusXM\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On the night of August 5, 2011, [[The Bronx
thumb: Bronx]]-based rapper [[Fat Joe]] was slated to host [[Funkmaster Flex]]'s birthday party at [[Webster Hall]]. During his performance, Fat Joe brought out French Montana to perform on stage. Controversy erupted as Jim Jones and his entourage, who were reportedly on the adjacent balcony seats, began hurling bottles and glass at the performers.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Fat Joe On The Fight Between Jim Jones And French Montana
column9: title=French Montana and Jim Jones have altercation at Webster Hall
column12: accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> The following day, videos of the incident were uploaded online, depicting French and his entourage facing a barrage of glass and liquor on stage, as they continued performing his rendition of \"Hard In Da Paint\" while facing the mentioned balcony with the crowd chanting along to it.<ref name=\"WebsterHall\">{{cite web
column14: title= Jim Jones vs French Montana at Webster Hall
column20: title= Jim Jones & Byrd Gang Throwing Ice & Bottles At French Montana While He Performs On Stage!
column23: accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> Some of the members on stage hurled debris back towards the balcony, as Jones and his entourage eventually exited the premises.<ref name=\"WebsterHall\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Fat Joe and Waka Flocka accompanied French Montana in his video shoot for \"Shot Caller\" later that month in August. The song, which made reference to [[Sean Combs
thumb: Diddy]]'s 1997 hit \"[[Its All About The Benjamins]]\", would soon garner the interest of the [[Bad Boy Records
250px]]: Bad Boy]] mogul. On October 9, French announced Diddy and [[T.I.]] for the official remix to the song.<ref name=\"ShotCallerRemix\">{{cite web
column5: title= French Montana Taps Diddy & T.I. for \"Shot Caller (Remix)\"
column9: accessdate=August 20, 2015}}</ref> [[DJ Drama]], who called it his favorite record, referred T.I. to jump on the remix.<ref name=\"ShotCallerRemix\"/> Although the T.I. feature never came to fruition, the remix was released on November 24, and featured rappers Diddy and Rick Ross.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: With \"Shot Caller\" already one of the most played tracks on New York radio, on stations such as [[Hot 97]] and [[Power 105]],<ref name=\"ShotCallerRemix\"/> French was slated to appear on the upcoming episode of BET's ''[[106 & Park]]'' on December 6,<ref name=\"BadBoyKonvict\">{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana To Announce Which Label He's Interested In During \"106 & Park\" Appearance
column6: accessdate=August 27, 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"BETBadBoy\"/> where he would be debuting the music video and announcing the label he's signing with. Diddy would also appear that night as part of his \"Bad Boy Takeover\" campaign, whereon the two officially announced that French Montana had signed to Bad Boy Records.<ref name=\"BETBadBoy\">{{cite web
column8: title=Diddy Announces French Montana Bad Boy Signing on 106 & Park
column11: accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> Between 2011–2012, \"Shot Caller\" had become one of the most added tracks on [[urban contemporary]] radio in the country.<ref name=\"SDinterview\"/> It was re-released as a single on January 10, and the music video for the remix was released in February 2012. A \"NY Giants remix\" premiered on [[Funkmaster Flex]]'s radio show on January 6, celebrating the [[New York Giants
column13: Super Bowl]] win against the [[New England Patriots
column16: title= New Music: French Montana \"Shot Caller (NY Giants Remix)\"

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: ===2012–16: Signing to Bad Boy and MMG===

Having received offers from several labels, including Jay-Z's [[Roc Nation]] and Kanye's [[GOOD Music]]; on December 6 on [[BET]], French Montana publicly announced signing with Bad Boy Records, an imprint of [[Interscope Records]]. In a subsequent interview with [[Billboard (magazine)
thumb: Billboard]] magazine, French revealed that had he not signed with Bad Boy that MMG would be his next choice.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title= Exclusive: French Montana Talks Bad Boy Signing, Upcoming Album & More
column8: accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> However, on January 4, 2012, while in the studio with Rick Ross, the two announced French's new signing to a joint-venture between Bad Boy Records and Maybach Music Group, making him a part of both labels.<ref name=\"JointVenture\">{{cite web
column10: title=French Montana Announces Maybach Music Group and Bad Boy Records Joint Venture
column18: title= French Montana Celebrates Bad Boy/MMG Alliance
column21: accessdate=August 27, 2015}}</ref> Both Ross and Diddy would be executive producing his debut [[studio album]].<ref name=\"JointVenture\"/><ref name=\"JointVenture2\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On January 6, the two dropped Ross' track \"[[Stay Schemin]]\" with rapper [[Drake (rapper)
thumb: Drake]]. Notable for its memorable French and Ross \"[[hook (music)
250px]]: hook]]\", the track became one of the biggest hits that year, oft-talked about for its Drake verse believed to be a \"diss\" towards rapper [[Common (rapper)
column4: Common]] at the time. French Montana was featured on [[XXL (magazine)
column7: Danny Brown]], [[Macklemore]], Don Trip, [[Hopsin]], [[Iggy Azalea]], [[Roscoe Dash]], and Bad Boy labelmate [[MGK]].<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=XXL Freshman Class Includes French Montana, Machine Gun Kelly
column17: accessdate=January 7, 2013}}</ref> French later revealed to host [[Sway Calloway]] on MTV's ''RapFix Live'' in August 2012 that he almost turned down the cover opportunity feeling he deserved it a year or two prior.<ref name=\"RapFixLive\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French's first single from the upcoming album, \"[[Pop That]]\" was released on June 15, featuring Ross, Drake and [[Lil Wayne]]. The song would be one of the biggest hits that year, and a still-popular club and summer anthem since. It is French's most successful commercial single, having been certified \"[[music recording sales certification
thumb: platinum]]\" by the [[RIAA]], and peaking at #2 on Billboard's [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs
column4: Rap]] charts and #36 on the [[Billboard Hot 100
column5: Hot 100]]. While initially expected for a release in July 2012, French's album went through several pushbacks until its finalized release date of May 21, 2013. The date which happened to coincide with the birthdays of Max B and famous labelmate the late [[Notorious B.I.G.]] In the meantime, French had released his fifteenth mixtape ''Coke Boys 3'' on April 13, 2012, which included collaborations with fellow Coke Boys [[Chinx Drugz]] and Cheeze, alongside the likes of Ross, Akon, [[Kevin Gates]] and [[Wale (rapper)
column6: Wale]]. Notable tracks among others include, a rare collaboration between French, Chinx and the late Stack Bundles on \"Tap That\", and \"Headquarters\" featuring [[Red Café]] and Chinx, the music video for which premiered on July 21.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In September 2012, French Montana was featured on the cover of the 82nd issue of [[The FADER]] magazine,<ref name=\"fader\"/> who joined French on his first homecoming to Morocco after seventeen years since his family moved to the United States in 1996. The article describes his journey through Morocco, meeting his mother's family, and eventually his estranged father who isn't made aware of his son's coming arrival.<ref name=\"fader\"/> French was accompanied by manager Gaby Acevedo, and youngest brother Ayoub, in addition to Zach Baron and Michael Schmelling of [[The FADER]]. The piece ends with an emotional reunion between the father and the two sons, including Ayoub who had previously never met their father before.<ref name=\"fader\"/>
French marked the end of the year with his sixteenth mixtape ''[[Mac & Cheese 3]]'' released on November 20, 2012.<ref name=\"FM16\"/> which included collaborations with [[Prodigy (rapper)
250px]]: Future]], Fat Joe, Ma$e, [[Rico Love]] and [[Trina]] among others. Acclaimed for its production and track selection, it was among the most downloaded mixtapes of all time.<ref name=\"FM16\"/> With several productions from [[Young Chop]], the music video to \"Devil Wants My Soul\" premiered on November 5, and an in-studio video of \"Ocho Cinco\" on November 26. Both songs would go viral, prompting another music video for \"Ocho Cinco\" – featuring Diddy, [[MGK]], Red Café and [[King Los]] – released in February 2013. The song was also included as a bonus track on the upcoming ''[[Excuse My French (album)
column4: Excuse My French]]'' album. The run up to which included further video releases, including the Black Metaphor produced \"Sanctuary\" on February 3, [[Swizz Beatz]] produced \"Diamonds\" featuring Ross and [[J. Cole]] on February 17, and Fraud produced \"State of Mind\" on May 15 and \"Intro (Only If For A Night)\" on November 30, among others. Since the tapes' premiere on [[DatPiff]], it would reach the 500K \"double platinum\" rating by first month, and presently stands at a \"diamond\" rating with over 1.4 million downloads on that site alone.<ref name=\"FM16\">{{cite web

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In January 2013, French announced his second single \"[[Freaks (French Montana song)
thumb: Freaks]]\", featuring [[Nicki Minaj]], from his upcoming album to be a remake of [[Vicious (rapper)
250px]]: Lil Vicious]]' 1994 song of the same name.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Check Out the Artwork for French Montana's Next Single \"Freaks\" Featuring Nicki Minaj
column8: accessdate=March 8, 2013}}</ref> The song premiered on Hot 97 on February 13, with the music video coming out on March 3. The remix, featuring an additional Ross, Wale, [[Mavado (singer)
column9: Mavado]] and [[DJ Khaled]], was released on April 25. A bonus track \"Marble Floors\" was released earlier on December 4, 2012, featuring Ross, Lil Wayne and [[2 Chainz]] with production from [[Mike WiLL Made It]]. It would fast become a viral hit, only to be outdone by French's third single \"[[Ain't Worried About Nothin]]\" released on April 15, 2013. The music video premiered on May 7, and would be the last before the release of his album on May 21. Subsequent music videos included, \"Trap House\" featuring Ross and [[Birdman (rapper)
column10: Birdman]] released on September 23, \"Gifted\" featuring [[The Weeknd]] on October 15, \"Once In A While\" featuring [[Max B]] on November 18, and \"Paranoid\" featuring Johnny May Cash on January 20, 2014, among others.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: His first solo single \"[[Ain't Worried About Nothin]]\" was a hit on radio stations, and a remix featuring Ross, Diddy and [[Snoop Dogg]] was released on October 4, and a second remix featuring [[Miley Cyrus]] on October 14. Upon its release, ''Excuse My French'' was met with mixed reviews from music critics.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=September 2, 2013}}</ref> It fared better commercially, debuting at number 4 on the [[Billboard 200
column7: ''Billboard'' 200]] chart, with first-week sales of 56,000 copies in the United States.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 5/26/2013
column11: accessdate=May 29, 2013}}</ref> The album also featured collaborations with [[Raekwon]], [[Scarface (rapper)

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Following the album release, French announced signing [[Chicago]]-based rapper [[Lil Durk]] to his Coke Boys. French, who is close to producer [[Young Chop]], had previously collaborated with Durk on his recent mixtape and with Chief Keef on his debut album the year before. Durk, Chinx and Young Chop appeared in the music video to \"Paranoid\", featuring Chop's brother Johnny May Cash. The song is inspired by French's brushes with death, including the late-2003 incident where he survived a gunshot to the head. Durk collaborated on several records with French in the coming years, starting with the remix to Durk's breakout single \"[[Dis Ain't What U Want]]\" featuring French, Ross and Meek Mill, released on November 27, 2013.
French appeared as a featured artist on several singles in 2013, most notably [[Joe Budden]]'s \"[[NBA (song)
thumb: NBA]]\" with Wiz Khalifa released on March 26; [[ASAP Ferg]]'s \"[[Trap Lord
250px]]: Work (Remix)]]\" – alongside [[Schoolboy Q]], [[ASAP Rocky]] and [[Trinidad James]] – on May 14; Canadian singer [[Massari]]'s \"[[Shisha (song)
column4: Shisha]]\" on May 21; and [[Will.i.am]]'s \"[[Feelin' Myself (will.i.am song)
column5: Feelin Myself]]\" with Miley Cyrus and Wiz Khalifa on November 26, among others.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Despite several pushbacks, French released his seventeenth mixtape ''Coke Boys 4'' on January 2, 2014,<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana Sticks To His Comfort Zone On 'Coke Boys 4' Mixtape
column6: accessdate=January 9, 2014}}</ref> which included collaborations with [[Snoop Dogg]], [[Wiz Khalifa]], [[MGK]], Mally Mall, [[Lil Durk]] and MeetSims, among others. The music video for the \"Paranoid (Remix)\" – featuring Diddy, Ross, Meek, Durk, Chinx and Jadakiss – was released on April 13. Subsequent music videos included, \"88 Coupes\" featuring Jadakiss released on May 15, \"God Body\" featuring Chinx on May 28, and \"Money Bag\" with Durk and Chinx on June 23. In a January 2014 ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' interview, French revealed that his next ''Mac & Cheese'' would be a studio album instead of a mixtape.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=French Montana Working With Kanye, Macklemore and Rick Ross

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 2014, French collaborated with Diddy on Ross' track \"[[Nobody (Rick Ross song)
thumb: Nobody]]\" released on February 19. Rick Ross' remake of the late Notorious B.I.G.'s 1997 song \"[[Life After Death
250px]]: You're Nobody (Til Somebody Kills You)]]\", featured an eerie chorus by French and interludes of Diddy in a live motivational rant. The song was inspired by Ross' brush against death the year before, when his [[Rolls-Royce Motors
column4: Rolls-Royce]] came under repeated gunshot fire while driving through [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida
column7: title=Rick Ross Masterminds Death-Defying Return: Video Q&A + Photo Shoot Behind-The-Scenes
column11: accessdate=March 23, 2014}}</ref> In a bizarre series of events, French Montana would experience a similar but unrelated event months later when his convoy came under fire on March 1 in [[Philadelphia]] during his \"Excuse My French\" tour after French had finished performing a show hours earlier.<ref name=\"MTVphilly2\">{{cite web
column13: title= French Montana Says He ‘Was Not Involved’ In Philadelphia Shooting
column18: title=Shooting Outside Rapper’s Tour Bus Leaves 1 Dead, 1 Wounded
column21: accessdate=July 21, 2015}}</ref> The music video premiered on February 27, 2014. Albeit met with mixed to positive reviews, the song would be a hit and was re-released as a single on March 3, 2014. French joined Ross for a live performance on the television program ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]'' on March 5, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Rick Ross Performs \"Nobody\" with French Montana on the \"Late Night with Seth Meyers\"

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French Montana would collaborate with fellow-Bronx native [[Jennifer Lopez]] on her comeback single \"[[I Luh Ya Papi]]\". The song premiered on LA's [[Power 106]] in March 5, and was released as a single on March 11, with the music video coming out two days later. The single was an international hit, and among the most added/played tracks on [[rhythmic contemporary]] radio in Canada. French also appeared in the music video to Fat Joe's single \"Stressin\", featuring Jennifer Lopez, which premiered in October later that year. French joined Rick Ross on [[Puff Daddy]]'s comeback single \"Big Homie\" from his upcoming album ''MMM''. With a guest verse by Ross and ad-libs by French, the single was released on March 24, with the music video premiering on March 31. French Montana joined Ross, Meek and veteran [[Jay-Z]] on [[DJ Khaled]]'s summer hit \"[[They Don't Love You No More]]\". The single was released on March 29, with the music video coming out on June 22 that year.
On July 17, teasers to the movie ''[[The Purge: Anarchy]]'' were released featuring music from French's upcoming single \"[[Don't Panic (French Montana song)
thumb: Don't Panic]]\". A month earlier, Instagram photos of the two showed French with then-girlfriend [[Khloé Kardashian]] on set with matching masks on, prompting speculation whether she was in the coming video. Following weeks of promotion, the single was released on August 12. The music video, which retained the dark themes of the movie while maintaining its catchy [[DJ Mustard]] character, became a viral hit. The couple had created bit of a stir two months earlier, on June 2, when Khloé posted an IG photo of the two on set of \"They Don't Love You No More\", depicting French holding a rifle in his arms with Khloé seated next to him with a bottle of liquor to her mouth. The remix to \"Don't Panic\", featuring Jeremih and Chris Brown, was released on October 14.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French Montana would join [[Remy Ma]] on DJ Khaled's \"They Don't Love You No More (Remix)\" released on August 2. Khaled's former [[Terror Squad (group)
thumb: Terror Squad]] affiliate and Bronx-native Remy Ma had just been released from prison the day prior. The three appeared together in the music video which premiered on August 23.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title= DJ Khaled Feat. Remy Ma & French Montana – They Don't Love You No More Remix
column6: accessdate=August 31, 2015}}</ref> This was her first musical comeback since her incarceration six years earlier. French collaborated with [[Ashanti (singer)
column7: Ashanti]] on her second single \"[[Braveheart (Ashanti album)
column8: Early In The Morning]]\" released on October 14 off of her comeback album, ''Braveheart''. This would be Ashanti's first album in six years.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French released his second single \"[[Bad Bitch]]\", featuring Jeremih, in December 2014, with the music video premiering on February 23, 2015. In late-October, French had announced his \"Set It Off\" tour with Jeremih, running up to his expected ''Mac & Cheese: The Album'' release in December. With the album eventually pushed back to next year; in its place, French released his collaborative [[extended play
thumb: EP]] with Harry Fraud, ''Mac & Cheese: The Appetizer'' on December 12, 2014.<ref name=\"FM18\">{{cite web
column4: title= French Montana – Mac & Cheese: The Appetizer
column6: date=December 12, 2014}}</ref> His eighteenth mixtape, ''The Appetizer'' marked a shift away from French's usual feature-heavy records. With Fraud's signature sample-heavy production, French blurred the lines between rap and R&B in a manner not unlike that of Max B, and with subject matter ranging from difficult life-decisions, women, addiction and memories of his bygone friendship with his now-incarcerated rap soulmate. In August 2015, French paired with pop-opera artist [[Charisse Mills]] for the single \"Champagne.\"<ref name = allhiphop>{{cite web
column8: title = Charisse Mills Ft. French Montana – \"Champagne\"

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On February 14, 2016, [[DJ Khaled]] announced that he would debut French's new mixtape on [[We The Best
thumb: We The Best Radio]].<ref name=\"DJ Khaled to premiere French Montana's mixtape\">{{cite web
column4: title=DJ Khaled to premiere French Montana's mixtape
column8: accessdate=February 14, 2016}}</ref> The mixtape, hosted by Max B, debuted on February 19, 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column14: accessdate=February 20, 2016}}</ref> On May 5, 2016, French's contract with Interscope and MMG ended, and he later signed a joint venture record deal with Bad Boy and [[Epic Records]].<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=French Montana Signs With Epic Records
column21: accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> Later, French was going to release his second studio album ''[[MC4 (mixtape)
column22: MC4]]'' in October 2016, however, the album's release was canceled after [[Target Corporation
column23: Target]] unofficially released the album on [[Compact disc
column24: CD]] on its original release date (August 19, 2016), two months before the album was set to release, which also managed to leak its entirety on internet as a [[internet leak
column25: leak]], plus some \"sample clearance issues\" on tracks like \"I'm Heated\" and 2 Times\".<ref name=\"Scrapped\">{{cite web
column28: title=French Montana Ain't Worried about Scrapping 'MC4' (Exclusive)
column31: accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> It was originally supposed to be the fourth installment in the \"Mac & Cheese\" series, and the first to be originally released as an album. French later stated that he's planning to start a new record label with Max B when he is released. On November 5, 2016, Montana unexpectedly released the album as a [[mixtape]] instead and premiered it on [[Drake (musician)
column32: Drake]]'s [[Beats 1]] radio show, [[OVO Sound]] radio later that night. Montana revealed in an interview with [[Zane Lowe]] on his [[Beats 1]] radio show that the first and second single from his upcoming project is ready to be released. He also announced a collaborative track with [[Chance the Rapper]] and [[Quavo]], produced by Ben Billions, a collaboration with [[Swae Lee]] that is \"just like 'Unforgettable'\", as well as a song called \"No Stylist\".<ref>{{cite news
column35: title=French Montana & Swae Lee Are Sitting On The Next \"Unforgettable\"
column40: title=New Music: Diplo, French Montana, & Lil Pump feat. Zhavia – 'Welcome to the Party'

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On July 14, 2017 Montana released ''[[Jungle Rules]]'' as his second album.
On December 6, 2019, French Montana released his third studio album ''[[Montana (album)
thumb: Montana]]'', which includes the song \"[[Writing on the Wall (French Montana song)
250px]]: Writing on the Wall]]\", a collaboration with [[Cardi B]], [[Post Malone]] and [[Rvssian]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Montana's charitable work started after he visited Uganda to film his \"[[Unforgettable (French Montana song)
thumb: Unforgettable]]\" video in 2017, a song that gained over a billion streams and held strong on the top 10 in the U.S. [[Billboard Hot 100]]. His efforts in Uganda raised half a million dollars to build the Suubi hospital which serves over 300,000 citizens of Uganda. <ref> {{cite news
column5: title= French Montana Launches Global Healthcare Initiative, Donates $100K to Mama Hope Organization in Uganda: Exclusive}}</ref>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 2018, French was given the honor of Global Citizen Ambassador for his charity work in the East African country, Uganda. This was the first time the honor has been bestowed upon a rapper.<ref> {{cite news
250px]]: title=French Montana Donated $100K to Uganda and Became Rap's First-Ever Global Citizen Ambassador

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Montana is fluent in his [[Languages of Morocco
thumb: native]] Arabic and French as well as in English.<ref name=\"fader\"/><ref name=\"StatusMag\"/> He cites being a father as one of his driving inspirations.<ref name=\"StatusMag\">{{cite news

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Montana has been a resident of the [[Pompton Plains, New Jersey
thumb: Pompton Plains]] section of [[Pequannock Township, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite news
column6: title= French Montana Talks New Album, Kanye and Media Attention on His Relationship With Khloe Kardashian
column11: quote= On a sweltering afternoon, a camera flashes on French Montana at his new house in suburban Pompton Plains, N.J.}}</ref> In 2016, he bought [[Selena Gomez]]'s [[Calabasas, California
column14: title= French Montana buys old crib

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Montana married Deen Kharbouch in 2007. The couple had separated by 2012, and their divorce was finalized in 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=French Montana: Rapper Officially Divorces Wife Dean Kharbouch
column9: title= French Montana – Ain't Worried 'Bout Nothin ... Finally Divorced
column13: date=October 3, 2014}}</ref> They have a son who was born in 2010.<ref name= worried />

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In June 2018, Montana became a [[citizen of the United States of America
thumb: U.S. citizen]].<ref>[http://www.tmz.com/2018/06/14/french-montana-becomes-u-s-citizen/ French Montana becomes US citizen] [[TMZ.com]] 2018/06/14</ref><ref>[http://www.thefader.com/2018/06/14/french-montana-united-states-citizen French Montana becomes United States citizen] ''The Fader'',  2018/06/14</ref>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 2003, two gunmen shot at Montana as he left a recording studio in New York, striking him in the head.<ref name=\"Life+Times\"/><ref name=\"CombatJack3\">{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana Casually Discusses Taking A Bullet To The Brain – The Combat Jack Show Episode 3
column6: accessdate=August 15, 2015}}</ref> He survived and was hospitalized for several weeks.<ref name=\"USmag\">{{cite web
column8: title=French Montana Says He's Not Dating Khloé Kardashian For Fame, Recalls Getting Shot In Head
column13: title=French Montana Talks Record Deal, Ross & Akon
column16: accessdate=September 2, 2013}}</ref> One of the gunmen died during the incident, in what is believed to be a case of \"[[friendly fire]]\" by one assailant against the other. Montana was investigated for the incident, but the case was eventually dismissed.<ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/><ref name=\"CombatJack3\"/><ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Shot In The Head & Beat Murder Case
column21: accessdate=August 9, 2015}}</ref> In early 2013, Montana visited the site of the shooting with a camera crew from Life+Times as he recalled the near-death experience and his life growing up in the Bronx. This was the first time he had visited the location since the attempted murder ten years earlier.<ref name=\"Life+Times\">{{cite web
column23: title=French Montana Tells His Story – The Genesis
column26: accessdate=July 21, 2015}}</ref> According to French, he was set up by someone close to him and his circle.<ref name= \"Life+Times\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French has been the owner of a number of pets, ranging from dogs to exotic animals such as [[tigers]] and a [[monkey]]. On April 22, 2013, French Montana posted an Instagram picture with the caption \"Got so high last night bought 2 baby tigers\". The picture was of French outdoors holding two tiger cubs, one on each arm.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana Gets High, Purchases Baby Tigers
column6: accessdate=July 22, 2015}}</ref> The tigers, named Ike and Tina, were prominently featured in French's music video for \"[[Excuse My French (album)
column7: The Gifted]]\" featuring friend and singer [[The Weeknd]], released later that year.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=BTS of French Montana and The Weekend's Music Video \"The Gifted\"
column14: title=French Montana and The Weekend Play With Tigers In \"The Gifted\" Video
column17: accessdate=July 22, 2015}}</ref>  In 2014, the rapper noted he had given up the two tigers shortly after getting them, citing the difficulty in feeding and caring for the animals.<ref name= \"Ridiculousness\">{{cite web

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Since late-2014, French Montana became the owner of a pet monkey named Julius Ceasor. A video of the animal was uploaded on December 18, showing French and record producer Mally Mall entering a private-jet with French then cradling the infant monkey in his arms.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=French Montana Introduces His Pet Monkey Julius Ceasor
column8: title=Exclusive: Mally Mall Gifts French Montana With a Monkey!

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: French Montana describes [[Tupac Shakur]], [[The Notorious B.I.G.]], [[Nas]], [[Snoop Dogg]], and [[Wu-Tang Clan]] among the hip hop artists he listened to growing up.<ref name=\"ComplexWIFM\"/><ref name=\"StatusMag\"/><ref name=\"BallerStatus2012\">{{cite web

thumb: French, later Norwegian ocean liner/cruise ship in service 1962-2005}}

250px]]: Compagnie Générale Transatlantique (CGT)]] liner launched in 1960

thumb: Ship flag           = [[File:Civil and Naval Ensign of France.svg
Ship fate           = Sold to Norwegian Cruise Line after 5 Years of decommission
Ship route          = [[Miami]], [[Key West]], [[Cozumel]], [[Roatán]], [[Great Stirrup Cay]], [[Miami]], and also European cruises
Ship builder        = [[Lloyd Werft]] (Refitting for Cruising Duties)
Ship out of service = 25 May 2003 (End of Revenue Service)
Ship decommissioned = 23 May 2005 (End of Internal Use By Norwegian Cruise Line)
Ship fate           = Sold for scrap in 2005
Ship status         = Scrapped in Alang, India 2008

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: '''SS ''France''''' was a [[Compagnie Générale Transatlantique]] (CGT, or French Line) [[ocean liner]], constructed by the [[Chantiers de l'Atlantique]] shipyard at [[Saint-Nazaire]], France, and put into service in February 1962. At the time of her construction in 1960, the {{convert
column5: abbr=on}} vessel was the longest [[passenger ship]] ever built, a record that remained unchallenged until the construction of the {{convert

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: ''France'' was later purchased by [[Norwegian Cruise Line]] (NCL) in 1979, renamed '''SS ''Norway''''' and underwent significant modifications that better suited her for [[Cruising (maritime)
thumb: cruising]] duties. She was renamed '''SS ''Blue Lady''''' and sold to be scrapped in 2006, and scrapping was completed in late 2008.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: ''France'' was the French Line [[flagship]] from 1961 to 1974, combining regular five days/nights [[transatlantic crossing]]s with occasional winter cruises, as well as two world circumnavigations. During her last years, to save fuel costs, crossings took six days/nights.{{Citation needed
As ''Norway'' she was the flagship of the [[Norwegian Cruise Line]] from 1980 to approximately 2001.{{Citation needed

Some, like ship historian [[John Maxtone-Graham]], believe that ''France'' was purposely built to serve as both a liner and a cruise ship, stating: \"Once again, the company had cruise conversion in mind... for cruises, all baffle doors segregating staircases from taboo decks were opened to permit free circulation throughout the vessel.\"<ref>Maxtone-Graham, John; ''Liners to the Sun''; Pg. 71</ref> However, others, such as ship historian William Miller, have asserted that ''France'' was the \"last purposely designed year-round transatlantic supership.\"<ref>Miller, William H.; ''Famous Ocean Liners''; Patrick Stephens Ltd.; 1987; Pg. 107</ref>
''France'' was constructed to replace the line's other ageing ships like {{SS
250px]]: SS ''Liberté'']], which were outdated by the 1950s.{{Citation needed
column4: date=December 2018}} Without these vessels the French Line had no ability to compete against their rivals,{{Citation needed
column6: Cunard]] Line, which also had plans for constructing a new modern liner. It was rumoured that this ship would be a 75,000-ton replacement for their ships {{RMS
column9: date=December 2018}} (This ship would eventually be the 68,000-ton ''[[Queen Elizabeth 2]]''.) Further, the [[United States Lines]] had put into service in 1952 {{SS
column10: United States}}, which had broken all speed records on her maiden voyage, with an average speed of {{convert

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: At first, the idea of two 35,000-ton running mates was considered to replace ''Ile de France'' and ''Liberté''. [[Charles de Gaulle]] (the future [[President of France]]) opined that it would be better for French national pride, then flagging due to the then ongoing [[Algerian War of Independence]], to construct one grand ocean liner, in the tradition of {{SS
thumb: Normandie}}, as an ocean-going showcase for France. The idea of such a publicly funded liner was controversial, leading to raucous debates in the French parliament. The dealing lasted three and a half years, and though the letter commissioning the construction was finally signed by the Chairman of the Compagnie Générale Transatlantique, Jean Marie, on 25 July 1956, debate about the form, cost and construction schedule for ''France'' lasted a further year.<ref name=\"ARC\">Offrey, Charles; ''303 Arts, recherces et créations'':SS Normandie/SS France/SS Norway: ''France'', the Last French Passenger Liner; p. 45</ref>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Beyond the luxuries, the French Line had to also face the realities that transatlantic passenger trade was forecast to decline due to increased air travel. Also, costs to operate ships were increasing, mostly due to prices of crude oil.{{citation needed
thumb: date=July 2012}}  Thus, the new ship would be larger than ''Ile'', but smaller and cheaper to operate than ''Normandie''. She would also only be a two-class liner, which would, like the recently built {{SS
250px]]: Rotterdam}}, be able to be converted from a segregated, class restricted crossing mode to a unified, classless cruising mode, thereby allowing the ship to be more versatile in its operations.{{Citation needed
column4: date=December 2018}} Despite these requirements, she was still to be the longest ship ever built, as well as one of the fastest, meaning not only an advanced propulsion system, but also a hull design which would withstand the rigours of the [[Atlantic Ocean
column5: North Atlantic]] at high speed.{{Citation needed

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Hull G19 was built by [[Chantiers de l'Atlantique]] shipyard, in [[Saint-Nazaire]], [[France]], her keel being laid down on 7 September 1957. She was built in a pioneering manner: rather than constructing a skeleton which was then covered in steel hull plating, large parts of the ship were [[Prefabrication
thumb: prefabricated]] in other cities (such as [[Orléans]], [[Le Havre]] and [[Lyon]]). The hull was fully welded, leading to weight savings, and two sets of stabilisers were fitted.<ref name=\"Offrey; p. 52\">Offrey; p. 52</ref>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: She was blessed by the Bishop of [[Nantes]], Monseigneur Villepelet, and launched on 11 May 1960, at 4:15 pm, by Madame [[Yvonne de Gaulle]], wife of the President, and was then named ''France'', in honour both of the country, and of the two previous CGT ships to bear the name. By 4:22 pm ''France'' was afloat and under command of tugs.<ref>Offrey; p. 54</ref> President De Gaulle was also in attendance at the launch, and gave a patriotic speech, announcing that France had been given a new ''Normandie'', they were able to compete now with Cunard's ''Queens'', and the [[Blue Riband]] was within their reach.{{Citation needed
column4: kn}} speed of ''United States'' would prove impossible to beat.{{Citation needed

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: After the launch, the propellers were installed (the entire process taking over three weeks), the distinctive funnels affixed to the upper decks, the superstructure completed, life boats placed in their davits, and the interiors fitted out. ''France'' then undertook her sea trials on 19 November 1961, and averaged an unexpected {{convert
250px]]: kn}}. With the French Line satisfied, the ship was handed over, and undertook a trial cruise to the [[Canary Islands]] with a full complement of passengers and crew. During this short trip she met, at sea, ''Liberté'' which was on her way to the shipbreakers.<ref name=\"greatoceanliners\">[http://www.greatoceanliners.net/index2.html SS France (III)/Norway]</ref>

thumb: New York]] took place on 3 February 1962, with many of France's film stars and aristocracy aboard.{{Citation needed

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On 14 December 1962, ''France'' carried the ''[[Mona Lisa]]'' from Le Havre to New York, where the painting was to embark on an American tour.{{Citation needed

column6: New Year's]] cruise to the [[West Africa]]n coast.]]

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: She sailed the North Atlantic run between [[Le Havre]] and New York for thirteen years. By the beginning of the 1970s jet travel was by far more popular than ship travel, and the cost of fuel was ever increasing. ''France'', which had always relied on subsidies from the French government, was forced to take advantage of these subsidies more and more.{{Citation needed

Using the ship's versatile design to its full potential, the CGT began to send ''France'' on winter cruises, which was off-season for the Atlantic trade. One design flaw was revealed when the ship reached warmer waters: her two [[swimming pool]]s, one each for first and tourist class, were both indoors; the first class pool deep within the ship's hull, and the tourist class pool on an upper deck, but covered with an immovable glass dome. The latter, perhaps, was the more aggravating in hot weather.{{citation needed
thumb: date=September 2017}} She also had limited outdoor deck space, with much of what was available protected behind thick glass wind-screens, useful on the North Atlantic, but frustrating when blocking cooling breezes in the tropics.{{Citation needed

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Nonetheless, ''France's'' cruises were popular, and her first world cruise took place in 1972. Too large to traverse the [[Panama Canal
thumb: Panama]] and [[Suez Canal]]s, she was forced to sail around [[Cape Horn]] and the [[Cape of Good Hope]]. That same year, with the destruction of the ''Seawise University'' (former [[RMS Queen Elizabeth
250px]]: RMS ''Queen Elizabeth'']]) by fire in [[Hong Kong]], ''France'' became the largest in-service passenger ship in the world.{{Citation needed

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Still, as the opening years of the decade progressed, the cruise market expanded, seeing the construction of smaller, purpose-built [[cruise ship]]s which could also [[Panamax
thumb: fit through the Panama Canal]]. Worse, in 1973 the [[1973 oil crisis
250px]]: Oil Crisis]] hit, and the price of oil went from US$3 to $12 per barrel. When the French government, at the end of the [[Trente Glorieuses]], realized that keeping ''France'' running would necessitate an additional ten million dollars a year, it opted instead to subsidize the then in-development [[Concorde]]. Without this government money, the French Line could not operate, and with a press release issued in 1974 it was announced that ''France'' would be withdrawn from service on 25 October that year.{{Citation needed

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: At that, the crew decided to take matters into their own hands: an eastbound crossing on 6 September, her 202nd crossing, was delayed several hours while the crew met to decide whether to strike then and there, in New York, or six days later outside [[Le Havre]].  Le Havre won, and the ship was commandeered by a group of French [[trade union]]ists who anchored ''France'' in the entrance to the port, thereby blocking all incoming and outgoing traffic. The 1200 passengers aboard had to be ferried to shore on tenders, while approximately 800 of the crew remained aboard.

The strikers demanded that the ship be allowed to continue to serve, along with a 35% wage increase for themselves. Their mission failed, and the night of the takeover proved to be the ship's last day of service for the CGT. It took over a month for the stand-off to end, and by 7 December 1974, the ship was moored at a distant quay in Le Havre, known colloquially as ''quai de l'oubli'' - the pier of the forgotten.<ref name=\"greatoceanliners\"/><ref>[http://perso.orange.fr/paquebot.france-norway/histoire/HistoireIndexQ.html SS France: Quai de l'oubli]</ref>

By that time ''France'' had completed 377 crossings and 93 cruises (including 2 world cruises), carried a total of 588,024 passengers on trans-Atlantic crossings, and 113,862 passengers on cruises, and had sailed a total of 1,860,000 nautical miles.<ref name=\"captainsvoyage\">[http://www.captainsvoyage.com/norwegian-cruise-line/ss-norway/timeline.htmlSS Norway: Timeline]{{dead link
[[File:2016 05 01 Norway ex France verläßt Lloyd Werft nach Umbau zu Kreuzliner IMG 7098.jpg
250px]]: ''Norway'' leaving Lloyd shipyards in Bremerhaven after conversion.]]

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The mothballing of ''France'' was met with dismay by much of the French population, resulting in a song by [[Michel Sardou]], titled ''Le France''.{{Citation needed

The ship sat in the same spot for approximately four years, with the interiors, including all furniture, still completely intact. There were no plans to scrap the ship, or to sell it. In 1977 Saudi Arabian millionaire [[Akram Ojjeh]] expressed an interest in purchasing the vessel for use as a floating museum for antique French furniture and artworks, as well as a casino and hotel off the coast of the south-east United States. Though he purchased the ship for $24 million, this proposal was never realised, and others were rumoured to have floated, including bids from the Soviet Union to use her as a hotel ship in the [[Black Sea]], and a proposal from China to turn her into a floating industrial trade fair.<ref name=\"greatoceanliners\"/>

In the end, the ship was sold in 1979 to Knut Kloster, the owner of [[Norwegian Caribbean Line]] for $18 million for conversion into the world's largest cruise ship. Just before ''France'' was renamed ''Norway'' one last marriage was performed aboard the ship at the quay in Le Havre. The wedding was performed by Rev. Agnar Holme, the Norwegian Seaman's chaplain. Greg Tighe, Director of Research and Corporate Development for NCL, was married to Lorraine Anne Evering (Tighe) in ''France's'' chapel. Witnesses included the ship's Captain, and several members of NCL's management team.
