* [[Kara Tointon]] – actress, Dawn Swann in ''[[EastEnders]]'' and film ''[[The Football Factory (film)
column4: title=''Basildon star Kara Tointon finds her voice in ITV’s the Halcyon'' - Evening Echo Richmond.M p.30 December 2016

thumb: James Tomkins]] – footballer, [[West Ham United FC]]<ref>{{cite web

250px]]: title=Denise Van Outen, famous people from Basildon

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111010015407/http://www.basildonradio.co.uk/ Basildon Radio] – Basildon local Internet Radio station

thumb: constituency_westminster1 = [[South Basildon and East Thurrock (UK Parliament constituency)
static_image_caption      = Basildon town square, looking east

column12: dən}}) is the largest town in the [[borough of Basildon]] with a population of 107,123 in the county of [[Essex]], [[England]].<ref>[http://countyelections.essexcc.gov.uk/MapOfDivisions.asp?DistrictID=7 Countyelections.essexcc.gov.uk] {{webarchive

column14: 0}} south of the city of [[Chelmsford]] and {{convert
column18: 0}} west of [[Southend-on-Sea]]. Nearby smaller towns include [[Billericay]] to the northwest, [[Wickford]] northeast and [[South Benfleet]] to the southeast. It was created as a [[New towns in the United Kingdom
column19: new town]] after [[World War II]] in 1948 to accommodate the [[London overspill
column28: url-status = dead}}</ref> from the conglomeration of four small villages, namely [[Pitsea]], [[Laindon]], Basildon (the most central of the four) and [[Vange]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The local government district of Basildon, which was formed in 1974 and received [[Borough status in the United Kingdom
thumb: borough]] status in 2010, encapsulates a larger area than the town itself; the two neighbouring towns of Billericay and Wickford, as well as rural villages and smaller settlements set among the surrounding countryside, fall within its borders. Basildon Town is one of the most densely populated areas in the county.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Some of Basildon's residents work in Central London due to the town being well connected in the county to the [[City of London]] and the Docklands financial and corporate headquarters districts, with a 36–58 minute journey from the three Basildon stations to [[Fenchurch Street Station
thumb: London Fenchurch Street]].<ref>[http://ojp.nationalrail.co.uk/service/planjourney/search Association of Train Operating Companies] National Rail enquiries</ref> Basildon also has access to the City via road, on the A127, and A13.
New towns in the United Kingdom}}

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The first historical reference to Basildon is in records from 1086. It is mentioned in the [[Domesday Book]] as 'Belesduna'.<ref>{{cite web
thumb: title = National Archive Summary Record for Basildon
accessdate = 8 November 2006}}</ref> The name 'Basildon' may be derived from the [[Old English language
250px]]: Anglo-Saxon]] personal name 'Boerthal' and the Anglo-Saxon word 'dun', meaning hill.<ref name=\"basildon1\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=6 August 2009}}</ref> In historical documents, this name had various forms over the centuries, including Berdlesdon, Batlesdon and Belesduna.<ref name=\"basildon1\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Railway service started in the 19th century to Pitsea (1856) and Laindon (1888) but it was only later that proposals to provide service to the new town of Basildon, shelved for many years because of concerns that it would simply become a commuter suburb of London, were eventually forced through. A significant number of modern-day residents do commute to London.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=Commuting in London CIS 2014-11 - GLA Intelligence p.July 2014

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: By the beginning of the 1900s, Basildon had evolved with much of the land having been sold in small plots during a period of land speculation and development taking placed haphazardly with building by plot owners ranging from shelters created from recycled materials to brick-built homes and with amenities such as water, gas, electricity and hard-surfaced roads lacking.<ref name=\"EL1108\">{{cite news
thumb: title=Once upon a time in ... Basildon

Billericay Urban District Council]] and [[Essex County Council]], concerned by lack of amenities in the area and by its development, petitioned the Government to create a New Town.<ref name=\"EL1108\" /> Basildon was one of eight 'New Towns' created in the South East of England after the passing of the [[New Towns Act 1946
column10: url-status = dead}}</ref> On 4 January 1949 [[Lewis Silkin]], Minister of Town and Country Planning, officially designated Basildon as a 'New Town'. Basildon Development Corporation was formed in February 1949 to transform the designated area into a modern new town. The New Town incorporated [[Laindon]] and [[Pitsea]]<ref name=\"basildon.com\"/> and was laid out around small neighbourhoods with the first house being completed in June 1951.<ref name=\"EL1108\" /> The first tenants moved into homes in Redgrave Road in Vange.<ref>{{cite web
column18: archivedate=26 February 2009  }}</ref> A large, illuminated town sign \"Basildon Town Centre Site\" at {{convert
column20: ft}} was erected in 1956 by the railway and stood until early construction was completed.<ref name=echo/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Since March 2010 Basildon has a miniature famous white Hollywood sign, reading \"Basildon\": at five feet tall, the new sign is one-ninth of the height of the Hollywood original. This was aimed \"to bring the town into the 21st century and to attract more visitors\"<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/essex/8591492.stm BBC News] 29 March 2010.</ref> part of a plan of landscaping and infrastructure improvements funded by £400,000 from the [[John Prescott
thumb: Prescott]]-spearheaded [[Thames Gateway]].  Opponents from all parties believe spending could have been directed toward social problems.<ref name=echo>{{cite web
column4: title=Basildon’s name was up in lights...54 years ago
column5: work=Echo}}</ref><ref>[http://metro.co.uk/2010/03/30/basildon-gets-hollywood-sign-essex-style-201615/ London Metro] \"Basildon Gets Hollywood Sign Essex Style\" 30 March 2010</ref>

column4: South Basildon and East Thurrock (UK Parliament constituency)

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The former constituency of [[Basildon (UK Parliament constituency)
250px]]: barometer of public opinion]] in [[general elections]].<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Basildon opens its doors to the big guns – UK Politics, UK
column11: last=Boggan}}</ref> The results of the constituency elections were the same as the overall result of general elections from 1983 to its abolition in 2010.<ref>{{cite news
column13: title=John Harris on former tabloid editor Andy Coulson's success as David Cameron's spin doctor | Media
column17: location=London}}</ref> Basildon was said to epitomise the working class conversion to Thatcherism during the 1980s, though the town did not vote Conservative in 1979. Nor did the Conservative Party ever hold an absolute majority in the town – its success was due to the split between the SDP and the Labour Party. [[Essex Man
column18: \"Basildon Man\" or \"Essex Man\"]] was coined to describe an aspirational working class voter.<ref>{{cite web
column22: date=9 April 2013}}</ref> The current MP is Conservative politician [[John Baron (MP)

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Due to boundary changes, in the 2010 General Election the [[Basildon and Billericay (UK Parliament constituency)
thumb: Basildon and Billericay]] constituency elected one MP and South Basildon and East Thurrock elected another MP. In terms of local politics Basildon District elects five Councillors to Essex County Council.<ref name=\"essexcc1\">{{cite web
column4: title=Essex County Council Election Results – Map Of Divisions
column10: archivedate=9 June 2009  }}</ref> Following the 2017 election the seats were split 2 to the Conservatives, 2 to Labour and 1 Independent. [[Noak Bridge]] has a [[Parish councils in England

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon was built like many new towns with each area being a planned community. These communities are now the local areas of the town:

* [[Pitsea]] - one of the original four villages that were incorporated into the new town. Pitsea itself is split into 7 distinct communities - Pitsea, Pitsea Mount, Eversley, Chalvedon, Northlands (formerly Felmores), Burnt Mills and Nevendon.
* [[Laindon]] - one of the original four villages that were incorporated into the new town.
* [[Vange]] - one of the original four villages that were incorporated into the new town.
* Fryerns - an area of Basildon which is located along Whitmore Way.<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> The name came from a nearby farm (reputedly the first farm compulsory purchased by the Basildon Development Corporation)<ref name=farms>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> and was formerly the home of [[Fryerns Comprehensive School]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * Craylands - an area between Fryerns and Pitsea, and was named after the former [[Fryerns Comprehensive School
thumb: Craylands County Secondary School]]. The area is under redevelopment by [[Swan Housing]] and has been renamed by them as Beechwood Village.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=''100 homes buy out for multi-million revamp of Craylands Estate, Basildon'' - Evening Echo Robinson.E p.18 March 2018

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * Barstable - an area situated along Timberlog Lane.<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> The area is named after the former [[Barstable Hundred]] and known for its local shopping parade Stacey's Corner. It was formerly home to both [[Barstable School]] and Timberlog Secondary School with the former being now part of the [[Basildon Academies]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * Kingswood - an area situated at the west end of Clay Hill Road.<ref>{{cite web
* Ghyllgrove - an area situated between the Town centre and Fryerns.<ref>{{cite web
* Lee Chapel South - an area situated between the Town centre and [[Basildon University Hospital]].<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=Lee Chapel South, Basildon - #Getoutside Ordnance Survey

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * Lee Chapel North - an area situated between [[Gloucester Park, Basildon
thumb: Gloucester Park]], Lee Chapel South and [[Laindon]]<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Lee Chapel North, Basildon - #Getoutside Ordnance Survey

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * [[Langdon Hills]] - an area situated south of Laindon.
* Dry Street - a small hamlet situated just south of Laindon and west of Vange.
* Great Berry - declared a village by [[Essex County Council]] in 2015, the area is situated west of Laindon.<ref>{{cite web
* [[Noak Bridge]] - an area just north of Pipps Hill and east of Steeple View.
* Steeple View - an area just north of Laindon and West of Noak Bridge.<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> It is so named because the steeples of Great Burstead Church, St. Mary the Virgin Church and St Nicholas Church, Basildon are visible from the area.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * Pipps Hill - an industrial area just north of [[Gloucester Park, Basildon
thumb: Gloucester Park]]  and west of Cranes.<ref>{{cite web

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * Cranes - an industrial area east of Pipps Hill. The name comes from the former Cranes Farm which stood on the site.<ref name=farms />

Basildon has a heavily developed industrial base. During the construction of the New Town, government grants were given to companies to set up their businesses in Basildon. Amongst the companies that took up these grants were [[Ford Motor Company]] (opened 1964), [[Carreras Tobacco Company]] (1959–1984), [[Yardley of London]] (1966–1998), [[Gordon's Gin]] (1984–1998), [[GEC-Marconi]] (now home to [[Leonardo MW]]).
Basildon has industrial areas situated in Laindon, Cranes Farm Road and Burnt Mills. Cranes Farm Road is currently home to [[CNH Industrial
thumb: CNH]] Tractor Plant, formerly owned by Ford. Argos opened a regional warehouse on Pipps Hill Industrial Estate in the 1990s. In 2015, an Amazon delivery base was opened in Christopher Martin Road.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=New Amazon delivery base in Basildon will create more than 200 new jobs

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: A datacentre hosting the European matching engine of the [[Intercontinental Exchange]] is located in Gardiners Lane, Basildon on the site of the former [[York International]] factory.<ref>{{Cite web
250px]]: title=York's Basildon factory to be closed down in restructuring
column8: title=Wall Street Back up Centre Could Close – Evening Echo p.22 April 2011

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 2017, [[Costa Coffee]] opened their new coffee roastery in Basildon. It is said to be Europe's biggest coffee roastery – quadrupling Costa's roasting capacity from 11,000 tonnes per year to 45,000 tonnes. The facility, which is dubbed \"Paradise Street\" stands at 85,690 ft and can handle around 24 tonnes of coffee beans per hour.<ref>{{Cite news
250px]]: title=Costa to serve up 2bn cups of coffee a year with Europe's biggest roastery

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The two main roads from London to Southend, the [[A13 road (England)
250px]]: A127]], pass to the south and north of the town respectively. Both are important commuter trunk roads, and also allow easy access to the [[M25 motorway
column4: M25]] and the rest of the motorway network. Locally, the A13 gives access to Pitsea and Vange, and the A127 gives access to [[Basildon town centre

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Within the town are six main roads which link to and from the A13 and A127; all of them include 'mayne' in their names.
* Nether Mayne runs from the town centre to the A13 at Five Bells junction, just west of Vange.
* Upper Mayne runs from the town centre to the A127 in the northeast corner of Laindon. Both this road and Nether Mayne form part of the A176, which continues north to Billericay.
* South Mayne runs from [[Northlands Park, Basildon
thumb: Norhtlands Park]] to the A13 at Pitsea.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * East Mayne runs from Northlands Park to the A127 near Noke Wood. Both this road and South Mayne form part of the A132, which continues north to Wickford.
* Broadmayne runs from the town centre to Northlands Park, connecting the four aforementioned roads. It forms the A1321.
* West Mayne runs from the centre of Laindon to the A127 at [[Dunton Wayletts]]. It forms part of the B148, which continues east from Laindon to Upper Mayne.
The town has three stations on the [[London, Tilbury and Southend Railway
thumb: London, Tilbury & Southend Line]]: [[Pitsea railway station
column5: Laindon]]. All are served by [[c2c]] trains running between [[Fenchurch Street railway station
column6: Fenchurch Street]] and [[Southend Central railway station
column8: Shoeburyness]]; trains serving Basildon and Laindon stations run via [[Upminster station

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Most bus services are provided by [[First Essex]], connecting the town to Billericay, Wickford, and other nearby towns. Other providers are [[Stephensons of Essex]] and [[NIBS Buses]].

As part of Basildon's redevelopment [[Essex County Council]] had proposed that the A127 undergo significant development at a cost of £15 million which was expected to be finished by March 2011. It was funded via the [[Community Infrastructure Fund]] (CIF). The project was completed, and was divided into three sections:
* '''Section 1''' – Eastmayne. Implementation of an additional lane northbound (600 metres approx.) and new drainage and footpath realignment.

* '''Section 2''' – Cranes Farm Road. Included dualling of the existing carriageway of which was already there (1500m approx.) and enhancing and upgrading junctions – with the creation of a dedicated left turn lane at the roundabout at Eastmayne to help ease traffic flows during busy hours at the junction.

* '''Section 3''' – Introduction of a new A176 junction at Pipps Hill. This included upgrading the east and westbound off slips to increase the capacity of vehicles and ease traffic flows. The implementation of queue detection and advanced warning signs was also added to this section of the road.<ref>{{cite web
column9: accessdate=21 March 2017}}</ref> Part of section 3 also saw the introduction of the new Hollywood sign for Basildon at the A176 junction.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Climate in this area has mild differences between highs and lows, and there is adequate rainfall year-round.  The [[Köppen Climate Classification]] subtype for this climate is \"[[Köppen climate classification#GROUP C: Mild Temperate/mesothermal climates
thumb: Cfb]]\" (Marine West Coast Climate/[[Oceanic climate]]).<ref>{{cite web
List of secondary schools in Essex
250px]]: List of primary schools in Essex}}

thumb: secondary schools]] in the Basildon district:

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon also has two FE colleges:
*[[South Essex College]] which is currently based on Nethermayne (formerly [[Thurrock and Basildon College]]) by Basildon University Hospital (planned to move to the town centre 2020).
*[[PROCAT]] – an engineering and construction FE college (formerly Prospects College) based at Pipps Hills.
New Campus Basildon – formerly part of [[SEEVIC College
thumb: SEEVIC]] and was based in Church Walk. It was announced in January 2017 that the college would be closing from September 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=The New College Basildon Studio School, in Great Oaks, Basildon, set to close after financial struggle – Evening Echo p.10 Jan 2017

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: [[Essex County Council]]'s Adult Community Learning service, ACL is based at Ely House, Churchill Avenue, while there are several private providers delivering apprenticeship, traineeship and business training.
Basildon has three senior men's football clubs, [[Basildon United F.C.
thumb: Basildon United]] and [[Bowers & Pitsea F.C.]] which both play in the [[Isthmian League]] North Division and Basildon Town, who play in the Essex Olympian Football League.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Basildon Town - The Prokit Essex Olympian Football League
column5: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> Basildon also has a senior ladies team AFC Basildon Women, who play in the National League Southern Premier.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=''Khassal's 17-minute hat-trick rescues Chichester Ladies'' - The Chichester Observer Newman.H p.12 November 2018}}</ref>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In rugby the town is represented in the London 2 North East League by Basildon R.F.C., while there is only local cricket played at Basildon and Pitsea C.C. in the Shepherd Neame Essex League Division 3. Basildon is home to the South Essex Gymnastics Club where Olympic champion [[Max Whitlock]] trains.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=''Max Whitlock in tune with his local radio! wins Gold!'' - Gateway97.8 Lawrence.D p.6 November 2015

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The town's main sporting facility is the Basildon Sporting Village,<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=''Live as Prince William and Kate Middleton visit Basildon Sporting Village'' - Daily Gazette p.30 October 2018
column4: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> that opened in 2011 and is based in Gloucester Park. The Village consists of an Olympic sized swimming pool; 8 court sports hall; climbing wall; athletics track and is home to the South Essex Gymnastics Club.<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> It was revealed in 2014 that more people swim in Basildon than anywhere else in the county<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=''Basildon's Top Dog for Swimming'' - Evening Echo
column10: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> and that 3.5 million people had visited the centre since it had opened.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=''3.5 million visit controversial Basildon Sporting Village'' - Evening Echo Burbidge.I p.5 May 2014
column13: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> There are also smaller leisure centres named The Place and Eversley Centre located in Pitsea which opened during the 1980s.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon golf course is based in the Kingswood district of the town.<ref>{{cite web

250px]]: Shops in the Eastgate Shopping Centre]]

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The town centre has a variety of high street stores. As well as shops and coffee houses in the open air East Walk and Town Square, there is the covered [[Eastgate Shopping Centre (Basildon)
thumb: Eastgate Shopping Centre]] which is home to over 100 retailers.<ref>{{cite web

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: When Eastgate opened in 1985, it was the largest covered shopping centre in Europe until the opening of the [[MetroCentre (shopping centre)
thumb: Metro Centre]]. Eastgate has undergone a number of face-lifts since 1985, with its most recent substantial refurbishment in 2007 at a cost of more than £10m.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Further shopping facilities in the town can be found at Westgate Shopping Park, while there is a pavement market selling fresh fruit and vegetables as well as household goods, which in 2018 moved to a new location in St. Martins Square.

Outside of the town centre there are retail parks at Pipps Hill and Mayflower on the A127, while there are smaller shopping centres in Laindon and Pitsea, which is home to a famous market that opened in the 1920s. There are several smaller shopping areas
located in each of the communities.

250px]]: Festival Leisure Park also known as \"Bas Vegas\"]]

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Festival Leisure Park is a trading [[leisure park]] located in the north of Basildon and owned by [[Aviva]].<ref>{{cite web
thumb: title = Leisure real estate market makes waves (appeared in Property Week February 1998)

accessdate = 8 November 2006}}</ref> The Festival Leisure Park, includes 15 restaurants, a bowling and arcade centre, a family and entertainment centre with play frame and dodgem car track, two hotels, a bar, a sixteen screen Cineworld cinema, two health clubs and a nightclub called Unit 7. The Festival Leisure Park is colloquially known as \"Bas Vegas\". The name originated from a proposed Casino development on the site. The site was previously home to the Aquatels park which hosted a zoo, ski slope and golf range that opened in 1972,<ref>{{cite web
column8: archivedate=19 April 2013}}</ref> which was replaced in 1982 by a conference venue called the Festival Hall<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=''MEMORIES: The day boxing great Muhammad Ali came to Basildon'' - Evening Echo p.4 June 2016
column14: accessdate=3 December 2018}}</ref> which was home to the [[MFI World Matchplay]] darts championship.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Darts Results - MFI World Matchplay - Darts Mad

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: A [[wakeboarding]] complex also opened in 2012, attracting both professionals and amateurs alike<ref>{{cite web
thumb: title = I’ll take you for a spin (appeared in Basildon Recorder)

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The Arts Centre was the first theatre in Basildon opening in 1968 in a temporary facility behind the then temporary council offices (on the site of the current Westgate shopping park). This was renamed The Towngate Theatre and Arts Centre in 1976, before being replaced by a new purpose built theatre as part of the new Basildon Centre on the opposite side for the former Towngate Road.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=''Every picture tells a story of Basildon’s very own theatre'' - Evening Echo Richmond.M p.1 October 2015

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 1989 the culture and history of the town was documented by the newly re-opened Towngate Theatre, when it commissioned a community play from [[Arnold Wesker]] for the town's 40th anniversary. The potted history that Wesker called \"Boerthel's Hill\"<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> was acted out by a 125 members of the community recording a fascinating history of London's East Enders who were the first Basildon residents.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon currently has one cinema - [[Cineworld]] which is located at the Festival Leisure Park. This was previously owned by [[Empire Cinemas]] but was purchased as part of $124m deal to purchase 5 cinemas.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=''Cineworld completes $124m deal for five Empire cinemas'' - ScreenDaily Grater.T p.28 July 2016
column4: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> It had opened originally as a [[United Cinemas International
column7: title=''Staff at Basildon Cinema celebrate 18 years of business'' - Evening Echo Critchell.M p.21 July 2016

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Previously Basildon's cinema was based in North Gunnells as an [[ABC Cinemas]] in 1971. This changed hands several times becoming a [[The Cannon Group, Inc.
thumb: Cannon]] and a Robins cinema before closing in 1999.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> The building is now home to the [[British Heart Foundation]] store.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=''Charity shop to open up old Basildon cinema'' - Evening Echo Hills.M p.1 October 2011
column8: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> Prior to this a cinema in [[Pitsea]] originally called The Broadway from 1930, before changing its name in 1955 as The Century, operated until its closure in 1966 when it was converted to a Bingo hall.<ref>{{cite web

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 2018 planning permission was granted for a new 10 screen Empire Cinema along with new restaurants on the site of Freedom House in Basildon town centre,<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=''Cinema is coming to Basildon town centre after plans approved'' - Evening Echo Hough.K p.25 July 2018
column4: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> with demolition of the current buildings on site starting in 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=East Square development in Basildon gets new contractor - Evening Echo published 29 January 2020

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon Central Library is now based in the Basildon Centre<ref>{{cite web
column7: archivedate=10 November 2014}}</ref> (since 1989), but had previously been in prefabs next to the temporary council offices on Fodderwick. There are also numerous smaller libraries across Basildon: Clay Hill Road in Vange,<ref>https://libraries.essex.gov.uk/library-locations-and-opening-times/vange-library/</ref> Pitsea Centre in Pitsea,<ref>https://libraries.essex.gov.uk/library-locations-and-opening-times/pitsea-library/</ref> Fryerns Library in Whitmore Way, and Laindon Library on New Century Road Laindon.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon is home to the [[Dunton Plotlands
thumb: Haven Plotlands Museum]] and was previously home to the National Motorboat Museum, which had been based at Wat Tyler Park.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=''Exhibits gather dust after motorboat museum closes'' - Evening Echo Austin. J p.2 September 2010
column5: accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> Currently there is not a museum dedicated to the history of Basildon, though plans had previously been made to site one at Wat Tyler Park.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title='' Basildon Borough Museum and Heritage group may get new home soon''- Evening Echo p.19 November 2010
column8: accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> As of 2018 there is still a campaign to have a museum created.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=''Exclusive: Campaigners gather outside council offices to call for Basildon heritage museum'' - The Yellow Advertiser Thomson. C p.10 October 2018

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Image:Pitsea War Memorial Howard Park west.jpg
250px]]: Pitsea War Memorial in Howards Park (Grade II<ref>{{NHLE

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Image:Ruined Hawthorn in Dunton Plotlands - geograph.org.uk - 1375134.jpg
Basildon was designed with large amounts of green spaces with [[Gloucester Park, Basildon
thumb: Gloucester Park]] dominating the centre of Basildon. Kent View Recreation ground in Vange<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=''In the news:- Kent View Road Recreation Ground gets Fields in Trust protection'' - Basildon Council p.4 June 2018
column6: Northlands Park]] in [[Pitsea]] are the other large green spaces. Other formal parks include Mopsies Park in Timberlog Lane,<ref>{{cite web
column9: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> and Howards Park in Pitsea.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon is also home to [[Wat Tyler Country Park]] which opened in 1984; Marks Hill Nature Reserve (opened 1981);<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=''Nature reserve is protected by trust'' - Evening Echo Cornell.A p.5 July 2018
column4: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> [[Vange Hill]]; One Tree Hill Country Park; Langdon Hill Country Parks and the RSPCA Nature Reserve at Bowers Marshes.<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> [[Essex Wildlife Trust]] run a large reserve at [[Langdon Nature Reserve

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Even though Basildon is a new town there are still traces of its historical past viewable. Old roads that once connected the villages have been incorporated into the new town – Clay Hill Road, Timberlog Lane, Rectory Road, Pound Lane, Church Road, Dry Street. Dry Street is a perfect example of old Basildon, as it is an undeveloped country lane that runs through One Tree Hill and Langdon Hill Country Parks and is home to several listed properties.<ref>{{NHLE
column9: desc=Dry Street Farmhouse, Dry Street, Basildon

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Other than St Martin's Church, most of the historical parish churches still exist. St Nicholas (13th century and Grade 1 listed<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=4 December 2018}}</ref>) sits proudly over [[Laindon]], from where Basildon can be seen clearly, however St Peter's (13th century Grade II* listed<ref>{{NHLE
column10: publisher=}}</ref> at Nevendon is hidden behind Sainsburys and is little known by its residents. St Michael's at Pitsea is said to be 13th century, but was rebuilt in 1870<ref>{{cite web
column13: publisher=}}</ref> and now only its Bell Tower remains on Pitsea Mount. The village of Basildon's parish church, Holy Cross (Grade II listed<ref>{{NHLE
column15: desc=Church of the Holy Cross, Basildon
column16: accessdate=4 December 2018}}</ref>) can still be seen in Church Road, while Vange's 14th-century church All Saints was remodelled in the 19th century and is set back from the London Road and is Grade II listed.<ref>{{NHLE
column18: desc=Church of All Saints, London Road

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Other buildings of note are the Barge Inn at Vange, the Broadway at Pitsea with its mock Tudor architecture built by Harold Howard in 1929, Cromwell Manor (formerly Pitsea Hall Grade II listed<ref>{{NHLE
column4: accessdate=4 December 2018}}</ref>) by Pitsea Rail Station that dates from the 15th century and Great Chalvedon Hall (Grade II listed<ref>{{NHLE
column7: accessdate=4 December 2018}}</ref> and now a pub) in Tyefields which is reputed to be 16th century. Nevendon Hall was built in 1789 and is Grade II listed.<ref>{{cite web

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: One notable building is Little Coopers Farmhouse which was originally located in Takeley. It was designated a Grade II building in 1980. In the late 1980s due to redevelopment, the whole structure was dismantled and re-built at the Wat Tyler Country Park.<ref>{{cite web
On the west side of town, the [[Dunton Plotlands]] area was occupied by small rural dwellings in the mid twentieth century. Today it forms [[Langdon Nature Reserve]].

thumb: National Lottery]] funded heritage trail was started to highlight the 1960s architecture.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=''Oxford, Edinburgh, York ... and Basildon? New town paves way for heritage trail '' - The Guardian Kennedy.M p.2 Jun 2008

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon has its own community radio station which is aimed towards the residents of Basildon, East [[Thurrock]], and its surrounding areas called Gateway 97.8<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=''Pat Sharp reveals Fun House revival wish as he launches weekly radio show at Basildon's Gateway 97.8'' - The Yellow Advertiser Thomson.C p.15 July 2016
column4: accessdate=3 December 2018}}</ref> which broadcasts from the Eastgate Shopping Centre.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: ITV [[London]] & BBC [[London]] are the local television regions received in the town. Basildon Development Corporation had installed a Cable Television service into many of its home – it was called [[Rediffusion]] , but this service stopped during the 1990s. The service was replaced by [[Telewest
thumb: United Artists Cable]] which were based in the town – this is now [[Virgin Media]] (although the customer service operation closed in the 2000s).
The Evening Echo]] newspaper offices have been based on the Pipps Hill Industrial Estate, while since 1976 the town has been home to The Yellow Advertiser.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon was the setting for the [[BBC]] programme [[White Gold (TV series)
column4: title=''White Gold: Inbetweeners writer honours Essex roots'' - bbcnews Halford.J p.24 May 2017
column5: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> with filming taking place in Basildon Town Centre. [[Channel 5 (UK)
column6: Channel 5]] programme Extreme Hair Wars was set at JET training academy in Basildon.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=''Basildon hair salon takes centre stage on television'' - Evening Echo Hough.K p.18 Jan 2018
column9: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> The fictional character [[Nellie Bertram]], played by [[Catherine Tate]] in the [[United States of America
column11: The Office]]'' was said to have been born in Basildon.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon had a great influence on the 1980s music scene with bands [[Depeche Mode]] and [[Yazoo (band)
thumb: Yazoo]], and later by [[Alison Moyet]] in her solo career and [[Vince Clarke]] in his role with [[Erasure]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The documentary film [[Newtown Utopia]] by Christopher Ian Smith was made about Basildon.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=''New Town Utopia review – how Basildon was delivered to the future'' - The Guardian Bradshaw.P p.3 May 2018
column4: accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> Basildon also hosts Europe's only Underwater film studio that can be inside or out, as it has a removal roof.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=''International Drama Films at The Underwater Studios'' - The Knowledge Daniels.N p.23 January 2014
column7: accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> The studios has been used to film scenes in the Anglo-French drama ''[[The Tunnel (TV series)
column8: The Tunnel]]'' and for the film ''[[47 Meters Down]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=''Afraid of sharks? ‘47 Meters Down’ cast faced real-life danger, pee-filled pool to make movie'' - Los Angeles Daily News Strauss.B p.12 June 2017

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon was the focus of ''Magic Party Place'' by photographer [[CJ Clarke]]. \"{{sic
column4: of}} a largely white working class community, the town is one of the most statistically average places in England\", he said.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=''Welcome to Basildon: the middle of Middle England – in pictures'' - The Guardian p.30 September 2016

thumb: Church Garden: the area in front of St. Martin's Church in Basildon Town Centre is landscaped
Brooke House, showing its v-shaped pylons

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: St. Martin's Church in Basildon town centre is a modern structure. The church was consecrated in 1962 by the Bishop of Chelmsford.  A freestanding glass Bell Tower was built in 1999 and opened by Her Majesty the Queen.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=St Martins of Tours – Around the Church

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Although there are a number of tall buildings in central Basildon, there are also many newly constructed buildings closer to the 'Basildon Enterprise Corridor' situated in North Basildon.<ref>[http://www.essex.gov.uk/Environment%20Planning/Planning/Transport-planning/Travel-improvements/Documents/BEC%20Final%20for%20printing.pdf Planning Dept] {{webarchive

The largest structure in the new town's town centre is Brooke House, a 14-story residential tower block that fronts the west side of the town centre's East Square. Dating from 1962, it was designed by Sir Basil Spence and Anthony B Davies, with [[Arup Group Limited
thumb: Ove Arup and Partners]] as the structural engineers.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141014004129/http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/default.aspx?pid=2&id=472020 English Heritage, listing information for Brooke House]</ref><ref>http://www.ribapix.com/index.php?a=indexes&s=item&key=IYToxOntpOjA7czo3OiJQaWxvdGlzIjt9&pg=137</ref> It has a 1960s [[Brutalist]] design, elevated on 8 massive V-shaped concrete pylons. The building was chosen to have a residential function, as opposed to commercial office space, to retain life in the town centre after the shops had closed. Shops were positioned to the rear of the building, with Brooke House acting as a covered forecourt. It was conceived as a structure to define Basildon's urban status and to act as marker to identify the town centre's location within a largely low-rise settlement set in a flat landscape.<ref name=\"ReferenceB\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Jennie Humphrey, \"Basildon Town Centre Heritage Assessment\", 2012
column8: url-status=dead }}</ref> It was named after the then Minister of Housing and Local Government, Henry Brooke MP. The building was given Grade II listing in 1998.<ref>{{NHLE

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: East of Brooke House is East Square, a sunken open-air public plaza accessed from Brooke House by a monumental staircase and a curved ramp which was listed in 1998 as Grade II.<ref>{{NHLE
250px]]: desc=Retaining Walls, Ramp, Steps, Bench and raised paving
column4: accessdate=4 December 2018}}</ref>  The east side of the square is fronted by Freedom House, containing shops on two levels, and the north side by the Post Office building, a 5-story structure. On a wall of Freedom House is the oldest piece of public sculpture in the new town: installed in 1957, it is a wire and aluminium relief by the sculptor [[John Poole (sculptor)
column5: A. J. Poole]] titled \"Man Aspires\".<ref>\"Our Basildon, exploring past, present and future, heritage trail\", http://www.visitessex.com/discover/cultural/Basildon_Heritage_Trail.aspx</ref><ref>George Thorpe, \"Treble Clef's 54-year secret solved at last\", The Echo, 5 January 2011. [http://www.echo-news.co.uk/news/8770053.Treble_Clef___s_54_year_secret_solved_at_last/]</ref> The whole ensemble was designed to create a formal setting for Brooke House, and has a similar Brutalist design, though softened by other architectural features. The town centre extends from East Square towards the south-west. Down the middle of this zone runs a rectangular raised pool. Within the pool is a bronze sculpture and fountain, titled \"Mother and Child\", by the sculptor [[Maurice Lambert]] and dating from 1959<ref name=\"ReferenceB\"/> which was listed as Grade II in 1998.<ref>{{NHLE

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On the Upper level of Eastgate is the Cats Cradle Pussiwillow III Clock. It was created by [[Rowland Emett]] in 1981 and was originally placed outside what is now ASDA on the Lower Mall of the shopping centre.<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=2015-12-31}}</ref> It was officially unveiled by [[Michael Bentine]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The Barstable School building first opened on 1 March 1962 and was designed by the Finnish architect Cyril Leonard Sjöström Mardall (of [[Yorke Rosenberg Mardall
250px]]: Yorke]], Rosenberg and Mardall). The building was listed in 1993 and is Grade II listed.<ref>{{NHLE
column6: accessdate=4 December 2018}}</ref> It is now home to the lower school of the [[Basildon Academies]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Basildon has gone through several regenerations - a few highlights are:.<ref>{{cite web
*Investment in the Basildon Enterprise Corridor, a large business area.
*The creation of a new wetland nature reserve in the [[North Kent Marshes
thumb: Thames Marshes]] by the [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] (RSPB), the Land Restoration Trust, [[Basildon District Council]] and [[Veolia]].

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: *A review of the district's housing, with investment in housing estates such as Craylands, Five Links and Felmores which will be re-designed to allow for less trouble and having more streets with roads, rather than a street with just pavement.
*The regeneration of Basildon and [[Laindon]] town centres.
*The creation of a health and education research centre near [[Basildon University Hospital]].

*There is a proposal for creating [[Dunton Garden Suburb]] on land between Basildon and Brentwood. This proposal may have 6,000 homes, together with retail, commercial and leisure uses. This is a joint proposal of the two councils and a public consultation ended in March 2015.<ref>{{cite web
thumb: title=Dunton Garden Suburb – Joint Project with Brentwood Borough Council
column5: accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> The proposal has been met with criticism from all political parties<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Parties unite to oppose Dunton Garden Suburb plans
column10: date=17 March 2015}}</ref> and the residents group Residents Against Inappropriate Development<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Say No to Dunton Garden Suburb

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: *In 2018 planning permission was granted for a new 10 screen Empire Cinema along with new restaurants on the site of Freedom House in Basildon town centre.

Previous incarnations of institutes with the name \"Gotham Academy\" includes ''[[The Batman]]'' and ''[[Young Justice]]'' television series, where it was the school of [[Dick Grayson]], [[Artemis Crock]], [[Barbara Gordon]] and others.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: * '''Magiclands''' - The Magiclands are seven different realms where magic reigns supreme and can only be accessed by a train station in the Rock of Eternity.<ref>''Shazam'' Vol. 3 #2. DC Comics.</ref>
** '''Darklands''' - A place where the soul goes upon their death.

** '''Funlands''' - A place that is made up of one big amusement park and is ruled by King Kid. Due to his hatred for adults, any kid who turns 18 will be placed in slavery to help maintain the Funlands.
** '''Gamelands''' - A dimension that is based around the video game concept. It requires 1,000,000 points to access the CPU needed to leave the Gamelands.

Each of its inmates are gathered throughout the Magiclands, including some from Earthlands. Superboy-Prime was also shown to be imprisoned here. Mister Mind stated to Doctor Sivana that the Monsterlands used to be called the Gods' Realm until the day of Black Adam's betrayal which led them to strip the gods of their powers and close the doors to the Magiclands.<ref>''Shazam'' Vol. 3 #10. DC Comics.</ref>

column7: title=We are at the START of #AmazingRace and we wanted to let you in on a secret, for the first time ever we have alumni from #BigBrother #Survivor and #AmazingRace competing against each other in a reality clash! And as @philiminator put it, \"it's going to be crazy time!\"
title='Amazing Race' films in Detroit; teams rappel down Guardian Building

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: '''''The Amazing Race 31''''' (also promoted as '''''The Amazing Race: Reality Showdown'''''<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=GET READY FOR A \"REALITY SHOWDOWN\" ON \"THE AMAZING RACE,\" NOW PREMIERING, WEDNESDAY, APRIL 17 AT 9 PM!
column6: accessdate=December 12, 2019}}</ref>) is the thirty-first installment of the reality television show ''[[The Amazing Race (American TV series)
column7: The Amazing Race]]''. This season features eleven teams of two – each consisting of contestants from previous seasons of ''[[Big Brother (American TV series)
column9: Survivor]]'', and ''The Amazing Race'' – in a race around the world for a US$1 million grand prize. The season premiered on April 17, 2019 and initially aired on CBS's Wednesday 9:00 pm [[Eastern Time Zone
column10: ET]] time slot following ''[[Survivor: Edge of Extinction]]''. Following ''Survivor''{{'}}s season finale, ''The Amazing Race'' was rescheduled to ''Survivor''{{'}}s former time slot of 8:00 pm starting May 22, 2019. The finale aired on its original Wednesday 9:00 pm time slot due to the premiere week for ''[[Big Brother 21 (American season)

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Life partners Colin Guinn and [[Christie Lee Woods
thumb: Christie Woods]] from ''[[The Amazing Race 5]]'' were the winners of this season of the ''Race''.

column4: The 31st season of ''The Amazing Race'' began on June 10, 2018 at the [[Hermosa Beach Pier]] and nearby beach in [[Hermosa Beach, California]].]]

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On June 10, 2018, the show announced on its social media accounts that the ''Race'' had begun filming and that the season's teams would be composed of contestants from [[List of programs broadcast by CBS#Reality / non-scripted
thumb: CBS's reality competition programs]].<ref name=\"Instagram\"/> On July 3, 2018, the show concluded in [[Detroit]], which featured a performance of [[The White Stripes]] single \"[[Seven Nation Army]]\" that was originally planned to be set on [[Belle Isle Park (Michigan)
250px]]: Belle Isle Park]]. However, the permit was denied as the [[Michigan Department of Natural Resources]] had not been informed about the large gathering of musicians needed for filming. This season marks the first visit to the state of [[Michigan]] in an ''Amazing Race'' franchise.<ref name=\"freepress\"/>

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In the lead-in to the [[2018–19 United States network television schedule
thumb: 2018-19 television programming season]], CBS had scheduled ''The Amazing Race 31'' to start airing on May 22, 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=CBS Doubles Down on Unscripted for Midseason
column9: work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}</ref> However, in early April 2019, CBS opted to bring the premiere forward to April 17, 2019, slotting the show in Wednesdays after ''Survivor'' and replacing the low-rated ''[[Million Dollar Mile]]'', which was pushed to a Saturday night slot.<ref name=\"premiere\">{{cite web
column11: title=CBS Moves ‘Amazing Race’ Premiere Up A Month, Bumps ‘Million Dollar Mile’ To Saturdays
column18: title=CBS Shifts ‘Million Dollar Mile’ to Saturdays After Just Two Episodes

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The ''Race'' traveled over 25,000 miles across four continent and ten countries, including a franchise-first visit to [[Uganda]] and the first visit to [[Laos]] for the American version.

thumb: Head-to-Head]] returned to this season after it was introduced in the [[The Amazing Race 30
column10: access-date=April 16, 2019}}</ref> This is also the first season to utilize the U-Turn Vote, which has been previously utilized by the [[HaMerotz LaMillion
column14: Filipino]] versions of ''The Amazing Race''.<!--Citation states, \"The U-Turn Vote has been used on four international versions of the show: Israeli, which first introduced it in its second season in 2011, Chinese, Australian and Filipino.\", so mentioning this fact is not SYNTH and complies with trivia guidelines.--><ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Here’s what you need to know about the U-Turn Vote twist on 'The Amazing Race'

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: During the season, [[Rachel Reilly]] broke the record for the number of legs run by a female racer at 32,<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title=Uh-oh! Rachel Reilly’s new 'Amazing Race' record is in jeopardy
column8: accessdate=November 29, 2019}}</ref> and Leo & Jamal broke the record for the number of legs run by a team at 34.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Leo and Jamal (‘Amazing Race’ exit interview) on that lock block: 'It definitely wasn’t one of our brightest episodes'
column15: accessdate=November 29, 2019}}</ref> Tyler & Korey and Colin & Christie also both tied the record for multiple season leg wins at 9 wins each.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Colin and Christie also tied these 3 'Amazing Race' records with their win
column22: accessdate=November 29, 2019}}</ref> This season is also the fourth time, after [[The Amazing Race 1
column25: Season 30]], in which the teams that finished in the top three of Leg 1 also made it to the final leg of the ''Race''.

250px]]: List of Survivor (American TV series) contestants
column4: List of Big Brother (American TV series) houseguests}}

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On May 4, 2018, a [[TMZ]] article reported that former ''Big Brother'' houseguests had been asked to compete on the upcoming season of ''The Amazing Race''.<ref>{{cite web
250px]]: title='THE AMAZING RACE' Cody and Jessica Inspire ALL 'BIG BROTHER' ALUM EDITION!!!
column6: accessdate=March 7, 2019}}</ref> Later that day, [[Andy Dehnart]] posted that former ''Race'' contestants had also been contacted for the same season.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Amazing Race season 31: Big Brother vs TAR all-star teams
column13: accessdate=March 7, 2019}}</ref> Martin Holmes from ''Inside Survivor'' then posted that former ''Survivor'' contestants were also in the mix.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Former Survivor Contestants on Season 31 of The Amazing Race

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: This season involved eleven teams, three of whom previously competed on ''Big Brother'', three of whom previously competed on ''Survivor'', and five of whom previously competed on ''The Amazing Race''. The competing teams and their prior placements on their respective shows are:<ref name=\"ew cast\">{{cite web

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: **Leo Temory and Jamal Zadran, cousins, finished 4th on [[The Amazing Race 23
