,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: [[Category:World War II prisoners of war held by the United Kingdom]]
[[Category:Recipients of the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves and Swords]]
[[Category:German prisoners of war in World War II]]
[[Category:Flotilla admirals of the German Navy]]","{{Infobox military person

thumb:
unit=''[[2nd U-boat Flotilla]]''
''[[1st U-boat Flotilla]]''
''[[7th U-boat Flotilla]]''
awards=[[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves and Swords]]

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: '''Otto Kretschmer''' (1 May 1912 – 5 August 1998) was a German naval officer and [[submarine]]r in [[World War II]] and the [[Cold War]].

From September 1939 until his surrender in March 1941, he sank 47 ships, a total of 274,333 tons. For this he received the [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves and Swords]], among other awards. He earned the nickname \"Silent Otto\" both for his successful use of the \"[[Silent running (submarine)
thumb: silent running]]\" capability of U-boats as well as for his reluctance to transmit radio messages during patrols. After the war, he served in the German Federal Navy and retired in 1970 with the rank of ''Flottillenadmiral'' (flotilla admiral).

250px]]: Neisse]], then in the [[German Empire]] on 1 May 1912 to Friedrich Wilhelm Otto and Alice new Herbig.{{sfn
column6: p=1}} His father was a teacher at the local ''Volkschule'' ([[primary school]]) where Otto attended from 1918–1921. He then moved to a ''Realgymnasium'' ([[secondary school]]).{{sfn
column9: p=1}} In the aftermath of [[World War I]] the Kretschmer family remained aloof from the political turbulence of the [[Weimar era]]. Kretschmer indulged in sporting pastimes and scientific interests. Kretschmer achieved good results in mathematics and chemistry and passed his ''[[Abitur]]'' (school-leaving certificate) at 17. The report contained the remark, \"Kretschmer demonstrated his extraordinary courage in many instances. He wants to be a naval officer.\"{{sfn
column12: p=2}} Kretschmer was too young to enlist at 17 and his father sent him to [[England]] to broaden his horizons. He enrolled at [[Exeter University]] (then University College of the South West of England) and studied under Professor Jacob Wilhelm Schopp (b. 1871), a German–born naturalised Briton. He mastered the [[English language]] and came to respect British education, its practical focus complemented his scientific and theoretical–based German background. His time in England shaped his view of them during the war; he was quick to believe in rumours of new British inventions during the war at sea.{{sfn
column15: pp=2–4}} He returned home upon his mother's death from tetanus in a medical malpractice incident. He did not return to England from his hiatus, but travelled through [[France]], [[Switzerland]] and [[Italy]].{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Kretschmer entered the ''[[Reichsmarine]]'' (Weimar Navy) on 1 April 1930 as ''See Offizier Anwärter'' (naval officer cadet). Kretschmer formed part of \"Crew 30\" (the incoming class of 1930), 78–strong intake of officer candidates.{{sfn
column4: p=3}} He underwent basic military training in the 2nd department of the standing ship division of the [[Baltic Sea]] in [[Stralsund]] (1 April 1930 – 30 June 1930).<ref group=Tr>2nd department —II. ''Abteilung''</ref><ref group=Tr>standing ship division —''Schiffsstammdivision''</ref> Kretschmer was then transferred to the [[training ship]] [[Niobe (schooner)
column5: ''Niobe'']] (1 July 1930 – 9 October 1930), attaining the rank of ''[[Midshipman
column6: Seekadett]]'' (midshipman) on 9 October 1930. Following a 14-month stay onboard the [[German cruiser Emden
column7: cruiser ''Emden'']] (10 October 1930 – 4 January 1932), he advanced in rank to ''[[Fähnrich zur See]]'' (officer cadet) on 1 January 1932.{{sfn
column14: pp=5–7}} The global cruise on ''Emden'' took Kretschmer to the [[Far East]] through the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and [[Suez canal]]. The ship made stops in [[Ceylon]], the [[Philippines]], [[China]] and [[Japan]]. Stops were made in [[Guam]], [[South Africa]], [[Angola]] and [[Spain]] on the return journey.{{sfn
column17: p=8}} The ''Emden'' returned to [[Wilhelmshaven]] on 2 December 1931. On 1 January 1932, Kretschmer and his crew mates were promoted to ''[[Fähnrich zur See]]'' ([[midshipman]]).{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Following his journey on ''Emden'', Kretschmer attended a naval infantry course for cadets at Stralsund (5 January–31 March 1932),<ref group=Tr>infantry course for cadets—''Infanterielehrgang für Fähnriche''</ref> before starting with the main cadet course at the [[Naval Academy Mürwik]] on 1 April 1932.<ref group=Tr>main cadet course—''Hauptlehrgang für Fähnriche''</ref> This course was interrupted by two brief assignments on the [[survey vessel]] [[Meteor (1915)
thumb: ''Meteor'']] (22–25 June 1932 and 10–15 October 1932) for navigation training. His training included a pathfinder course for cadets at Kiel (28 March −22 April 1933),<ref group=Tr>pathfinder course for cadets—''Sperrlehrgang für Fähnriche''</ref> an artillery course for cadets at Kiel-Wik (23 April – 28 June 1933),<ref group=Tr>artillery course for cadets—''Artillerielehrgang für Fähnriche''</ref> a torpedo course in [[Mürwik]] (29 June – 18 August 1933),<ref group=Tr>torpedo course for cadets—''Torpedolehrgang für Fähnriche''</ref> an anti-aircraft artillery course at Wilhelmshaven (19–31 August 1933),<ref group=Tr>anti-aircraft artillery course for cadets—''Fla-Waffenlehrgang für Fähnriche''</ref> a communication course for cadets at Mürwik again (1–3 September 1933),<ref group=Tr>communication course for cadets—''Nachrichtenlehrgang für Fähnriche''</ref> and his first U-boat course at Mürwik (25 September – 1 October 1933).{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On 2 October 1933, Kretschmer then transferred to the pocket battleship [[German cruiser Deutschland
thumb: ''Deutschland'']] as a gunnery officer during a trip to [[Denmark]]. This stay was interrupted for an aerial defense training course at Warnemünde (5–10 March 1934).<ref group=Tr>aerial defense training course for cadets—''Luftschutzlehrgang für Fähnriche''</ref> On 19 March 1934, his stay on ''Deutschland'' ended and he was transferred to the light cruiser {{ship
column10: p=41}} Kretschmer was present for gunnery exercises in the [[North Sea
column11: North]] and [[Baltic Sea]]. At [[Eckernförde]] on the 25/26 July 1934 Hitler boarded the ship to observe the exercise.{{sfn
column14: pp=8–9}} During this assignment, Kretschmer was promoted to ''Oberfähnrich zur See'' (Senior Ensign) on 1 April 1934.{{sfn
column18: p=41}} During another torpedo training course at Flensburg-Mürwik (27 September – 21 December 1934), Kretschmer received his commission as ''[[Leutnant zur See]]'' on 1 October 1934.{{sfn
column22: pp=41–42}} On 22 December 1934, Kretschmer was again on ''Köln'' serving as the ship's second torpedo officer.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 1933 [[Adolf Hitler]] and the [[Nazi Party]] came to power. The establishment of the ''[[Wehrmacht]]'' (Nazi German Armed Forces) in 1935 divided the major branches of the armed forces. The ''Reichsmarine'' was renamed the ''[[Kriegsmarine]]'', a Nazi creation. The [[OKM]] was established as the supreme command of the navy responsible for all facets of [[naval warfare]]. The renaming of the navy was a symbolic gesture, to erase the unpleasant memories of the 1920s and symbolise a new era.{{sfn
column4: p=110}} According to one historian, Kretschmer was a patriot and loyal to the government, but later \"eschewed Nazi efforts to glorify his success through [[Nazi propaganda

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: During Kretschmer's stay on ''Köln'', he attended an [[aircraft catapult]] course at [[Travemünde]].<ref group=Tr>aircraft catapult course —''Katapultlehrgang''</ref> On 26 September 1935, he was transferred to the 1st department of the standing ship division of the North Sea in Wilhelmshaven where he served as a company officer until 25 January 1936.{{sfn
column5: p=42}} Kretschmer joined the U-boat service in January 1936. After the completion of his submariner training he was promoted to ''[[Oberleutnant zur See]]'' (sub-lieutenant){{sfn
column12: p=42}}  Kretschmer's first operational experience on a submarine was as a lieutenant on the {{GS
column15: 2}} in 1937 as first watch officer under the command of [[Klaus Ewerth]] and then [[Hans-Rudolf Rösing]]. Rösing brought his own watch officer, and Kretschmer was demoted to second watch officer. While discharging his responsibilities for the operational readiness of the deck gun, Rösing dived leaving Kretschmer stranded in the freezing water. He clung to the periscope in the hope of being seen through the optics. Kretschmer was soon missed and the boat surfaced to find him before he succumbed to the cold.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: He was given interim command of ''U-35'' in August 1937, and this appointment coincided with [[German involvement in the Spanish Civil War
thumb: Germany's involvement]] in the [[Spanish Civil War]]. The boat was ordered to patrol the [[Bay of Biscay]] off the Spanish-French border. The crew were permitted ashore at the resort town of [[San Sebastian]]. Rösing's successor, Hermann Michahelles was killed in a car accident and Kretschmer assumed command for two weeks.{{sfn
column5: pp=14–15}} ''U-35'' returned to Germany after an uneventful patrol during which no ships were sunk. On 1 October 1937, Kretschmer took command of {{GS
column11: p=14}} Through the remaining [[Interwar period]], Kretschmer developed his own approach to combat. He dispensed with the standard practice of firing salvos, instead he practiced a \"one torpedo one ship\" policy as a means to achieving utmost efficiency with munitions. Kretschmer favoured surfaced attacks as opposed to the recommended submerged engagement.{{sfn
column14: pp=15–19}} Kretschmer was promoted to ''[[Kapitänleutnant]]'' ([[captain lieutenant]]) on 1 June 1939.{{sfn

thumb: German invasion of Poland]] on 1 September 1939 began the war in Europe. [[Karl Dönitz]],  [[Befehlshaber der Unterseeboote]] (BdU), ordered attacks on Allied shipping at sea, beginning the [[Battle of the Atlantic]]. The short range of the [[Type II submarine]] allowed for operations in the North Sea, but no further.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Kretschmer and ''U-23'' had departed from Wilhelmshaven on 25 August, one week before the start of World War II. His first patrol, with ''Oberleutnant zur See'' [[Adalbert Schnee]] as first watch officer, took ''U-23'' into the [[North Sea]] and along the coast of the Netherlands. The boat returned to Wilhelmshaven on 4 September.{{sfn
column5: p=43}} Further patrols took ''U-23'' around the [[Coastline of the United Kingdom
column6: British coast]]. The main area of operations were the seas and estuaries off  [[East of England]] and [[Scotland]], with mine-laying operations in the [[Baltic Sea
column7: Baltic]], to counter the [[Royal Navy Submarine Service]] at the end of 1939.{{sfn
column10: p=37}} A second patrol (9–21 September) yielded no success either.{{sfn
column13: p=254}} Kretschmer departed Kiel for the third war patrol on 1 October. On 4 October 1939 he sank the coastal ship [[List of shipwrecks in October 1939#4 October
column16: link=off}}). The small freighter was carrying pulp and [[Ferrochrome]]. Kretschmer waited for the crew to take to the lifeboats before destroying the ship with a torpedo.{{sfn
column19: p=107}} He returned to Kiel, rather than Wilhelmshaven, on 16 October. The next day, Kretschmer was awarded the [[Iron Cross]] 2nd Class ({{lang

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The fourth patrol (1–9 November) was unsuccessful.{{sfn
column4: p=254}} On his fifth patrol (5–15 December) he was ordered to explore the inner waters around the [[Orkneys]] and engage any remaining [[Home Fleet]] units that had departed [[Scapa Flow]] in the aftermath of [[Günther Prien]]'s attack.{{sfn
column8: Danish]] [[List of shipwrecks in December 1939#8 December
column11: link=off}} on 7 December. The ship was accompanied by three other vessels, but she was darkened and the black out aroused Kretschmer's suspicions. 19 men were killed in the sinking; only two were saved.{{sfn
column14: pp=180–181}} Following this patrol, he received the Iron Cross 1st Class ({{lang
column16: Eisernes Kreuz erster Klasse}}) on 17 December.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: ''U-23'' departed from Kiel on 8 January 1940 for its sixth war patrol and Schnee had been replaced by ''Oberleutnant zur See'' [[Hans-Dietrich von Tiesenhausen]].{{sfn
column6: Norwegian]] [[List of shipwrecks in January 1940#11 January
column9: link=off}} was sunk on 11 January 1940 without warning. The single torpedo attack killed 11 men. Only five sailors survived.{{sfn
column12: p=450}} Kretschmer's next success came in the Inganess Bay, [[Kirkwall]], where he attacked and sank the Danish {{GRT
column14: link=off}} tanker [[List of shipwrecks in January 1940#12 January
column18: p=9}} while she lay at anchor. There were no deaths among the crew. {{sfn
column21: p=451}} Kretschmer returned to Wilhelmshaven on 15 January. Three days later he departed for his seventh war patrol.{{sfn
column24: p=254}} Another neutral Scandinvian ship was sunk. The Norwegian [[List of shipwrecks in January 1940#24 January
column27: link=off}} sank east of the [[Shetland]]. The attack was conducted with no prior warning and consequently all 15 crewmen died.{{sfn
column30: p=453}} ''U-23'' returned to port on 29 January. He departed Wilhelmshaven for his eighth war patrol on 9 February.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On 18 February, Kretschmer sank the 1,300 ton [[United Kingdom
column6: 2}} off the [[Pentland Firth]] while she was escorting convoy HN 12 from [[Norway]]. {{sfn
column9: p=14}}  The destroyer crew lifted the black-out curtains making the attack easy. A single torpedo was fired, then Kretschmer ordered a u-turn and sped away on the surface; the destroyers neither sighted him nor detected him with [[ASDIC]]. {{sfn
column12: p=106}} Kretschmer sighted the British submarine, [[HMS Thistle (N24)
column13: ''Thistle'']] soon afterwards, and fired a second torpedo which missed.  The submarine was sunk weeks later by ''U-4''.{{sfn
column16: p=106}} 157 of the ''Daring'' crew were killed, including Commander Sydney Cooper. Only five survived.{{sfn
column24: link=off}} sank in the [[Moray Firth]]. All 33 men aboard died.{{sfn
column27: p=459}} [[List of shipwrecks in February 1940#22 February

250px]]: link=off}}, was sunk on 22 February. The ship had been torpedoed by ''U-57'' and abandoned.{{sfn
column6: p=459}} Kretschmer returned to Wilhelmshaven on 25 February after 17 days at sea—his longest to date.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On 2 April 1940, after eight patrols on ''U-23'', Kretschmer was ordered to the [[Friedrich Krupp Germaniawerft
thumb: Germaniawerft]], the shipbuilding works in Kiel, for construction training of the new [[German Type VII submarine
column6: 2}}. He commissioned ''U-99'' on 18 April 1940 which was part of the [[7th U-boat Flotilla]].{{sfn
column13: p=30}} After two months' training and shakedown manoeuvres in German waters, Kretschmer took the boat into action on 18 June 1940.{{sfn
column17: p=45}} On 21 June, his ninth patrol, his boat was damaged by an [[Arado Ar 196]] floatplane from {{ship
column21: 2}} in the belief ''U-99'' was a British submarine.{{sfn
column25: p=73}} ''U-99''{{'}}s first patrol ended in Wilhelmshaven on 25 June.{{sfn

250px]]: ''[[Kapitänleutnant]]'' Kretschmer receiving his Knight's Cross from the hands of ''[[Großadmiral]]'' [[Erich Raeder]], August 1940]]

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: During ''U-99''{{'}}s first four patrols, Kretschmer commenced attacking convoys at night on the surface, sinking merchant ships with highly accurate shots, using only one [[torpedo]] per target ship; the quote \"one torpedo ... one ship\" is attributed to Kretschmer around this time. His particularly brazen and risky innovation was to execute these night surface attacks inside the convoy. Admiral [[Sir George Creasy]] considered the manoeuvre so dangerous he thought it had been done by mistake.{{sfn
column4: p=31}} Kretschmer's tenth patrol (27 June–21 July) yielded over {{GRT
column10: p=256}} After sinking ''[[List of shipwrecks in July 1940#5 July
column11: Magog]]''—the submarine's first victim—Kretschmer gave the crew a bottle of brandy and directions to Ireland.{{sfn
column15: p=80}} Acts of compassion in submarine warfare were \"selective and fickle\" one historian wrote when describing Kretschmer's rescue of a lone man in a raft. Haunted by him, Kretschmer ordered the boat to backtrack until the survivor was found. They provided clothes and alcohol, then transferred him to a lifeboat at the first opportunity.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Among the victims was the [[Estonia]]n ship, ''Merisaar'', {{GRT
250px]]: link=off}}. Kretschmer captured the vessel, the only such ship seized by ''U-99''. The crew abandoned ship and were questioned by Kretschmer. The German crew failed to sink the stationary vessel with torpedoes while the weather ruled out the use of the gun. A prize crew boarded to sail it to [[Bordeaux]]. The ship did not reach port. German aircraft bombed and sank it three days later. Kretschmer docked in [[Lorient]] on 21 July.{{sfn
column6: pp=87, 256}} The BdU acquired new bases along the French Atlantic coast after the [[Battle of France]].{{sfn
column9: p=770}} A notable failure on the patrol occurred in the interception of [[SS Manistee (1920)
column10: HMS ''Manistee'']]. Kretschmer attempted to sink the ship with gunfire, but return fire and the appearance of an aircraft forced him to submerge. Under water ''U-99'' had  no chance of catching her.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Four days later Kretschmer began his eleventh patrol which concluded on 5 August. This third patrol on ''U-99'', took the boat into the North Atlantic, into the [[North Channel (Great Britain and Ireland)
thumb: North Channel]] and west of Ireland. He sank four ships and damaged three.{{sfn
column6: p=45}} His greatest success was the sinking of ''[[List of shipwrecks in July 1940#28 July
column9: link=off}} ship on 28 July followed by another two totalling {{GRT
column11: link=off}} on 29 and 31 July. Kretschmer was guided onto convoy OB-191. The 28-ship convoy was poorly defended by a destroyer and a [[corvette]]. Kretschmer was presented with an opportunity to put his one torpedo, one ship into practice.{{sfn
column14: pp=98–101}} Kretschmer hit and sank ''[[List of shipwrecks in July 1940#31 July
column22: p=264}} while damaging three others including the {{GRT
column24: lnk=off}} ''[[List of shipwrecks in August 1940#2 August
column25: Strinda]]''. The ships used barrels for ballast to prevent them sinking. The crew remained in lifeboats nearby for reboarding once the attack was over.{{sfn
column28: pp=98–101}} Following his third war patrol with ''U-99'', Kretschmer was awarded the [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross]] ({{Lang
column30: Ritterkreuz des Eisernen Kreuzes}}) on 4 August. The presentation was made by Dönitz following his return to Lorient.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On ''U-99''{{'}}s fourth war patrol from 4 to 35 September 1940,{{sfn
column5: p=45}} Kretschmer formed part of a [[wolfpack (naval tactic)
column6: wolfpack]] that struck against [[Convoy HX 72]]. The convoy suffered heavy losses while the U-boats escaped unscathed. Kretschmer sank one and damaged two–which he and Prien dispatched the following day.  [[Joachim Schepke]] arrived in ''U-100'' and sank seven. [[Heinrich Bleichrodt]] hit and sank two. 12 ships were sunk in total.{{sfn
column10: pp=40–41}} Kretschmer's logbook recorded the chaos. It noted the destroyers \"did not know how to help\" and busied themselves firing star shells on a moonlit night.{{sfn
column13: p=41}} The following month, Kretschmer formed part of the pack that attacked and devastated [[Convoy SC 7]]. Bleichrodt reported it and Dönitz succeeded in bringing multiple boats in on it. Kretschmer sank six and disabled a seventh.{{sfn
column18: Heinrich Petersen]] for the Knight's Cross after twelve war patrols for saving ''U-99'' from enemy detection. The nomination was approved on 5 November 1940. Petersen had served as Kretschmer's helmsman on every war patrol on both ''U-23'' and ''U-99''.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In November and December 1940 ''U-99'' sank three British [[Armed Merchant Cruiser
column7: 6}}. ''Laurentic'' and ''Patroclus'' were attacked on the night of 3/4 November.{{sfn
column10: pp=35, 37}} 51 men died aboard ''Laurentic'', 367 survived. ''Patroclus'' lost 56 crew; 230 survived.{{sfn
column14: p=68}} Kretschmer was awarded the 6th [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves]] ({{lang
column16: Ritterkreuz des Eisernen Kreuzes mit Eichenlaub}}) on 4 November 1940.{{sfn
column19: p=474}} ''U-99'' docked four days later, concluding Kretschmer's fourteenth patrol after just ten days at sea.{{sfn
column23: p=255}} Upon reaching port, he was summoned to Berlin to meet [[Erich Raeder]]. He was given the opportunity to convey his opinions on the state of the U-boat war. Kretschmer purportedly confined his remarks to the lack of air support from the ''[[Luftwaffe]]'', a point Raeder was fully aware. Kretschmer then met Hitler at the [[Reich Chancellery]] and he repeated his opinions on the war situation. Hitler invited Kretschmer to sit in on a lunch meeting with Hitler and [[Vyacheslav Molotov]], the [[Soviet Union]]'s ambassador to the Third Reich. Kretschmer's thoughts on Hitler and the subsequent conference are not known.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Kretschmer departed for his fifteenth patrol on 27 November and returned on 12 December.{{sfn
column5: p=255}} In December Kretschmer tried to intercept [[Convoy HX 90]] but encountered only stragglers.{{sfn
column8: p=46}} ''Forfar'' was one and during the sinking, ''HMS Viscount'' appeared forcing Kretschmer to dive. He assumed most of the crew went down with the ship; but there were 159 survivors. 176 men died.{{sfn
column12: pp=74, 76–77}} ''Laurentic'' and ''Patroclus'' had been loaded with wooden barrels to increase [[buoyancy]]. It took nine torpedoes and one dud to sink them; the latter was sunk after it stopped to pick up survivors from the former.{{sfn
column16: p=72}} Kretschmer was forced to engage ''Patroclus'' with the deck gun when it appeared to resist the torpedo damage but retreated when the ship fired back. A [[Short Sunderland]] appeared briefly, and Kretschmer was forced to accomplish the destruction of the ship with torpedoes, submerged.{{sfn
column20: p=72}} On 7 December 1940, Kretschmer sank the Dutch freighter ''[[List of shipwrecks in December 1940#7 December
column21: Farmsum]]''; the last success of the year. The ship was loaded with coal, set for [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]. The ship sank slowly. Kretschmer learned its identity from frantic radio signals.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Several of Kretschmer's senior officers departed the boat before the final patrol. [[Klaus Bargsten]] served aboard ''U-99'' under Kretschmer, before being promoted to captain himself and becoming the sole survivor of {{GS

On 22 February 1941 ''U-99'' left Lorient for the final time. For 13 days Kretschmer sailed without success. ''U-99'' tried in vain to assist Prien in ''U-47'', against OB 290. Prien achieved several sinkings, Kretschmer did not; the pair was chased off by destroyers. Prien's reports were picked up by the Luftwaffe which sent [[Focke-Wulf Fw 200]]s from I. ''[[Organization of the Luftwaffe (1933–45)#Gruppe
250px]]: ''Kampfgeschwader'' 40]] (KG 40—40th Bomber Wing) to attack the convoy. The air crews sank eight and damaged several more. Kretschmer continued to search for stragglers and found ''SS Holmlea''. He fired a single torpedo that missed before he lost the ship in thick mist. Prien sank the ship the following day. Prien and Kretschmer cooperated frequently during the course of this patrol - neither would complete it.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: The operation against [[Convoy OB 293]] proved disastrous for the Lorient group. Prien, Kretschmer along with {{GS
column7: 2}} attacked the convoy. The ships were protected by an escort group of two [[destroyer]]s, {{HMS
column23: p=62}} As with the group that would eventually sink Kretschmer ten days later, they were experienced and competent.{{sfn
column26: p=52}} Kretschmer attempted a surface night attack using his favourite tactic.{{sfn
column29: pp=187–190}} On 7 March Kretschmer sank two ships from the convoy including the {{GRT
column31: link=off}} ''[[list of shipwrecks in March 1941#7 March
column35: p=45}} Four ships were sunk, but two U-boats were sunk, one of them ''U-47''. Prien along with his crew disappeared, presumably in a depth charge attack.{{sfn
column39: pp=62–63}} British reports of the action mention a large red glow appearing deep below the surface amid the depth charge explosions.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On 16 March 1941 Kretschmer attacked [[Convoy HX 112]]. Kretschmer sank all but one of the ships lost by the convoy.{{sfn
column4: p=46}} During a counterattack by the escorts ''U-99'' was disabled after repeated [[depth charge]] attacks by the destroyers {{HMS
column14: p=77}} ''U-99'' was driven down to 700 feet—beyond the recognised [[crush depth]]— before control was regained and the ballast tanks blown.{{sfn
column17: p=53}} Kretschmer surfaced and, under fire from the British vessels, scuttled his boat. Three of his men were lost, but Kretschmer and the remainder of ''U-99''{{'}}s crew were captured. That same day the British escorts scored another success against the ''Kriegsmarine'' when the noted U-Boat skipper, [[Joachim Schepke]], was killed aboard {{GS
column20: 2}}, having been depth charged, rammed and sunk by ''Vanoc''.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Kretschmer's usual standards of conduct were evident during the sinking of his boat. One signalman sent a message to the escorts \"we are sinking\" and the firing stopped.{{sfn
column4: p=53}} He then sent a message to BdU, \"Two destroyers—depth charges—50,000 tons—Kretschmer.\"{{sfn
column7: p=53}} Kretschmer signalled ''Walker'' asking for rescue for his men, taking care to ensure as many left the submarine as possible, and assisted some of his crew towards the rescue nets hung from the British destroyer. Kretschmer's strength was evidently failing in the cold ocean; his own rescue was at the hands of a British sailor who climbed down the nets and plucked him from the water.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Kretschmer and his crew were landed in [[Liverpool]]. They were sent to [[Lime Street Station]] to be transported to London for interrogation. Kretschmer was taken separately but his crew had to negotiate the streets of Liverpool and were subjected to missiles thrown by angry civilians; the city [[Liverpool Blitz
thumb: had been heavily bombed]] and was closely linked with the Atlantic war. He was transported to the [[London Cage]], a facility for [[MI19]] to hold valuable enemy prisoners. The building was located at number 8 [[Kensington Palace Gardens]].{{sfn
column5: pp=230–232}} [[Winston Churchill]] disclosed the capture of Kretschmer to the [[House of Commons]] on 21 March. German radio acknowledged the capture and the death of Schepke. Prien's demise was not disclosed. German propagandists feared the triple loss might be too damaging to morale.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: Once in London, Royal Navy interrogators questioned the crew. The report, filed in the archives, was named [http://www.uboatarchive.net/U-99A/U-99INT.htm \"U 99\" Interrogation of Survivors April, 1941\"]. The British reported noted of Kretschmer, \"His political views were less extremely Nazi than had been assumed.  On seeing the craters of a stick of bombs near [[Buckingham Palace]] he was genuinely shocked that an attempt had so obviously been made by his countrymen to bomb the Palace. He spoke English quite well, though he lacked practice.  His whole demeanour was calm and quiet, and he seemed anxious to be friendly; he was also less suspicious of British Officers than was his First Lieutenant. Kretschmer stated that he was unmarried.\"<ref>[http://www.uboatarchive.net/U-99A/U-99INT.htm \"Interrogation of U-99 survivors\"]</ref>

Of his personality and view of the war it stated, \"He gave the impression of being a quiet, deliberate man, and looked more like a student than a U-Boat Captain. He prided himself on being able to take advantage of whatever the passing moment offered and made no elaborate plans for attacking convoys. He admitted that he had become weary of the war some time ago, and latterly had got no satisfaction from sinking ship after ship.
Following his capture, Kretschmer spent almost seven years as a [[prisoner of war]] (POW) in the hands of the British at No1 POW camp [[Grizedale Hall]]  in [[Cumbria]].{{sfn
column4: p=202}} In March 1942, the prisoners were transported to Bowmanville Camp near [[Lake Ontario]] in [[Canada]].{{sfn
column7: p=230}} During his captivity, Kretschmer was promoted in rank to ''[[Korvettenkapitän]]'' (corvette captain) on 19 March 1941, effective as of 1 March 1941, and to ''[[Fregattenkapitän]]'' (frigate captain) on 1 September 1944. In addition, he was awarded the [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves and Swords]] ({{lang
column9: Ritterkreuz des Eisernen Kreuzes mit Eichenlaub und Schwertern}}) on 26 December 1941. He was the fifth member of the German armed forces to be so honored.{{sfn

thumb: ''U-570'']] was captured by the Royal Navy. The officers were also taken to the prisoner-of-war camp at Grizedale Hall.{{sfn
column5: p=347}} Kretschmer was senior officer at the camp. An illegal \"[[Court of Honor
column6: Court of Honour]]\" was convened and headed by Kretschmer. They tried commander Hans-Joachim Rahmlow, ''[[Trial in absentia
column7: in absentia]]'', and ''U-570''{{'}}s other officers. Rahmlow and his second-in-command, Bernhard Berndt, were found \"guilty of cowardice\"; the other two officers were \"acquitted\". On the night of 18/19 October, Berndt escaped from the camp. A detachment of the [[Home Guard (United Kingdom)
column8: Home Guard]] apprehended him, shooting him when he tried to escape. Allied courts and Rahmlow sought justice against Kretschmer after the war, but he was never vigorously pursued for trial for his role in the death of Berndt.{{sfn
column11: pp=222–228, 238, 240}} Kretschmer was involved in a second illegal court of honour hearing against the commander of {{GS
column14: 2}}. Its commander , Hugo Förster, was repatriated to Germany and committed suicide before the end of the war.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In 1943, the German command tried to rescue him (in [[Operation Kiebitz
thumb: Operation ''Kiebitz'']]) but that daring plan failed. Four of those years were spent in Canada at [[Bowmanville POW camp]]. Kretschmer was released from captivity on 31 December 1947 and returned to [[Germany]].{{sfn

Donald McIntyre]] returned Kretschmer's [[binoculars]], which he had kept in 1941. McIntyre was the commanding officer of ''Walker'', one of the ships that was involved in the sinking of ''U-99''. At the time, Kretschmer was president of the [[:de:Deutscher Marinebund
250px]]: ''Deutscher Marinebund'']], a member club of the [[International Maritime Confederation]].{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: On 1 December 1955, Kretschmer joined [[West Germany]]'s navy, at the time named the ''[[Bundesmarine]]'' (Federal Navy), holding the rank of ''Fregattenkapitän''. He participated in the 2nd officers training course held at the former [[NS-Ordensburgen
column5: group=\"Note\"}} There, he became inspection group leader at the acceptance organization.<ref group=Tr>inspection group leader at the acceptance organization—''Prüfgruppenleiter bei der Annahmeorganisation''</ref> On 16 June 1956, he was tasked with the creation of [[:de:Schulgeschwader (Bundesmarine)
column6: 1. ''Geleitgeschwader'']] (1st Escort Squadron) which he commanded from 3 January to 15 October 1957. He then attended a training course (16 October 1957 – 28 February 1958) for [[amphibious forces]] in the United States.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: From 1 March to 31 October 1958, Kretschmer served as ''Admiralstabsoffizier'' (Asto—officer of the admiralty staff) with the [[:de:Flottenkommando
thumb: Fleet Command]]. On 1 November 1958, he was transferred to the position of commander of the ''Bundesmarine''{{'}}s [[:de:Amphibische Gruppe
250px]]: ''Amphibische Streitkräfte'']] (\"amphibious forces\"), a position he held until 15 January 1962. During this command, he was promoted to ''[[Kapitän zur See]]'' (captain at sea/captain) on 12 December 1958.{{sfn
column7: p=43}} On 16 January 1962, Kretschmer was appointed head of the department for naval task force training and naval tactics with the [[Armed Forces Staff (Germany)
column8: ''Führungsstab der Marine'']] (Navy Staff) with the [[Federal Ministry of Defence (Germany)
column9: Federal Ministry of Defence]].<ref group=Tr>head of the department for naval task force training and naval tactics—''Leiter des Referates Verbandsausbildung und Seetaktik''</ref> On 28 August 1963, he was transferred to the [[NATO Defense College]] in Paris.{{sfn
column13: p=43}} Kretschmer served in this function until 18 June 1964 when he was appointed chief-of-staff of the [[Allied Forces Baltic Approaches
column14: ''Befehlshaber der Seestreitkräfte der Nordsee'']] (German national Commander Naval Forces North Sea). On 1 June 1965, he was promoted to ''[[Flottillenadmiral]]'' (flotilla admiral), a rank which he initially held on probation. That day, he was made chief-of-staff of the NATO command [[Allied Forces Baltic Approaches
column15: COMNAVBALTAP]] at [[Kiel]], taking command on 15 June. Six months later, on 15 December, he officially became ''Flottillenadmiral''. His command ended on 31 March 1969. The next day, Kretschmer was transferred to the [[:de:Amt für Militärkunde
column16: ''Amt für Militärkunde'']] (Department of Military Studies), retiring on 30 September 1970.{{sfn

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: In later years Kretschmer was often interviewed for television and radio programmes about the Second World War; he appeared in the British 1974 documentary series ''[[The World at War]]''. In the mid-1990s he was interviewed for the computer simulation game ''[[Aces of the Deep (video game)
thumb: Aces of the Deep]]'', as one of several former U-boat skippers whose input was excerpted specially for the CD-Rom version of the game.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: While on holiday in [[Bavaria]] in the summer of 1998, Kretschmer died in an accident during a boating expedition on the [[Danube]] to celebrate his 50th wedding anniversary, at the age of 86. He was on a holiday cruise from [[Regensburg]] to [[Budapest]] when he tried climbing some almost vertical steps. A fall caused fatal injuries. His body was cremated, and his ashes were scattered at sea.

,safe,MYLARRRR,"[[File:Fresno State word: [[Category:World War II prisoners of war held by the United Kingdom]]
